            Healthcare
           </span>
          </a>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-30">
        <a href="#Culture">
         <span class="tocnumber">
          8
         </span>
         <span class="toctext">
          Culture
         </span>
        </a>
        <ul>
         <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-31">
          <a href="#Arts">
           <span class="tocnumber">
            8.1
           </span>
           <span class="toctext">
            Arts
           </span>
          </a>
         </li>
         <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32">
          <a href="#Architecture">
           <span class="tocnumber">
            8.2
           </span>
           <span class="toctext">
            Architecture
           </span>
          </a>
         </li>
         <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-33">
          <a href="#Sports">
           <span class="tocnumber">
            8.3
           </span>
           <span class="toctext">
            Sports
           </span>
          </a>
         </li>
         <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-34">
          <a href="#Cuisine">
           <span class="tocnumber">
            8.4
           </span>
           <span class="toctext">
            Cuisine
           </span>
          </a>
         </li>
         <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-35">
          <a href="#Media">
           <span class="tocnumber">
            8.5
           </span>
           <span class="toctext">
            Media
           </span>
          </a>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-36">
        <a href="#See_also">
         <span class="tocnumber">
          9
         </span>
         <span class="toctext">
          See also
         </span>
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-37">
        <a href="#Notes">
         <span class="tocnumber">
          10
         </span>
         <span class="toctext">
          Notes
         </span>
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-38">
        <a href="#References">
         <span class="tocnumber">
          11
         </span>
         <span class="toctext">
          References
         </span>
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-39">
        <a href="#Further_reading">
         <span class="tocnumber">
          12
         </span>
         <span class="toctext">
          Further reading
         </span>
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-40">
        <a href="#External_links">
         <span class="tocnumber">
          13
         </span>
         <span class="toctext">
          External links
         </span>
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
     </div>
     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
       Etymology
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Turkey" title="Name of Turkey">
       Name of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The name of Turkey (
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
       Turkish
      </a>
      :
      <i>
       Türkiye
      </i>
      ) is based on the
      <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">
       ethnonym
      </a>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
        Türk
       </a>
      </i>
      . The first recorded use of the term "Türk" or "Türük" as an
      <a href="/wiki/Exonym_and_endonym" title="Exonym and endonym">
       autonym
      </a>
      is contained in the
      <a href="/wiki/Old_Turkic_alphabet" title="Old Turkic alphabet">
       Old Turkic
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Orkhon_inscriptions" title="Orkhon inscriptions">
       inscriptions
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrks" title="Göktürks">
       Göktürks
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       Celestial Turks
      </i>
      ) of Central Asia (c. 8th century).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        [30]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The English name
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Turkey" title="Name of Turkey">
        Turkey
       </a>
      </i>
      first appeared in the late 14th century and is derived from
      <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">
       Medieval Latin
      </a>
      <i>
       Turchia
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TurkEtymology_32-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TurkEtymology-32">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Greek
      <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">
       cognate
      </a>
      of this name,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Turkey" title="Name of Turkey">
        Tourkia
       </a>
      </i>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
       Greek
      </a>
      :
      <span lang="el">
       Τουρκία
      </span>
      ) was used by the
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
       Byzantine
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Byzantine_emperors" title="List of Byzantine emperors">
       emperor and scholar
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_VII_Porphyrogenitus" title="Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus">
       Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus
      </a>
      in his book
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/De_Administrando_Imperio" title="De Administrando Imperio">
        De Administrando Imperio
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PrinzingSalamon1999_34-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PrinzingSalamon1999-34">
        [33]
       </a>
      </sup>
      though in his use, "Turks" always referred to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magyars" title="Magyars">
       Magyars
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Howorth2008_35-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Howorth2008-35">
        [34]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Similarly, the medieval
      <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">
       Khazar Empire
      </a>
      , a Turkic state on the northern shores of the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
       Black
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">
       Caspian
      </a>
      seas, was referred to as
      <i>
       Tourkia
      </i>
      (
      <i>
       Land of the Turks
      </i>
      ) in Byzantine sources.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
       <a href="#cite_note-36">
        [35]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      was sometimes referred to as
      <a href="/wiki/Names_of_the_Ottoman_Empire#Historic_maps_using_the_alternative_names_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Names of the Ottoman Empire">
       <i>
        Turkey
       </i>
       or the
       <i>
        Turkish Empire
       </i>
      </a>
      among its contemporaries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fatih.edu.tr_37-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fatih.edu.tr-37">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Turkey" title="History of Turkey">
       History of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_of_Anatolia_and_Eastern_Thrace">
       Prehistory of Anatolia and Eastern Thrace
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Anatolia" title="Prehistory of Anatolia">
       Prehistory of Anatolia
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Balkans" title="Prehistory of the Balkans">
       Prehistory of the Balkans
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" title="Ancient Anatolians">
       Ancient Anatolians
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_kingdoms_of_Anatolia" title="Ancient kingdoms of Anatolia">
       Ancient kingdoms of Anatolia
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">
       Thracians
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg/220px-G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg/330px-G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg/440px-G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli2012-21.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Some
        <a href="/wiki/Henge" title="Henge">
         henges
        </a>
        at
        <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">
         Göbekli Tepe
        </a>
        were erected as far back as 12,000 BC, predating those of
        <a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">
         Stonehenge
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">
         England
        </a>
        by almost ten millennia.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
         <a href="#cite_note-38">
          [37]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="335" data-file-width="446" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg/220px-Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg/330px-Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg/440px-Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Loewentor-Hattusa.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The Lion Gate in
        <a href="/wiki/Hattusa" title="Hattusa">
         Hattusa
        </a>
        , capital of the
        <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">
         Hittite Empire
        </a>
        . The city's history dates back to the 6th millennium BC.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whcunesco_39-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-whcunesco-39">
          [38]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatolian_peninsula" title="Anatolian peninsula">
       Anatolian peninsula
      </a>
      , comprising most of modern Turkey, is one of the oldest permanently settled regions in the world. Various
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" title="Ancient Anatolians">
       ancient Anatolian
      </a>
      populations have lived in
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
       Anatolia
      </a>
      , from at least the
      <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
       Neolithic
      </a>
      period until the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" title="Hellenistic civilization">
       Hellenistic period
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon2011_15-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon2011-15">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Many of these peoples spoke the
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">
       Anatolian languages
      </a>
      , a branch of the larger
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European_language_family" title="Indo-European language family">
       Indo-European language family
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UCLA_40-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UCLA-40">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In fact, given the antiquity of the Indo-European
      <a href="/wiki/Hittite_language" title="Hittite language">
       Hittite
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Luwian_language" title="Luwian language">
       Luwian
      </a>
      languages, some scholars have proposed Anatolia as the hypothetical center from which the Indo-European languages radiated.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnatoliaIndoEuropean_41-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AnatoliaIndoEuropean-41">
        [40]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The European part of Turkey, called
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Thrace" title="Eastern Thrace">
       Eastern Thrace
      </a>
      , has also been inhabited since at least forty thousand years ago, and is known to have been in the
      <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
       Neolithic
      </a>
      era by about 6000 BC.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MET_16-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MET-16">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">
       Göbekli Tepe
      </a>
      is the site of the oldest known man-made religious structure, a temple dating to 10,000 BC,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArchMag_42-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-42">
        [41]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while
      <a href="/wiki/%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Çatalhöyük">
       Çatalhöyük
      </a>
      is a very large Neolithic and
      <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">
       Chalcolithic
      </a>
      settlement in southern Anatolia, which existed from approximately 7500 BC to 5700 BC. It is the largest and best-preserved Neolithic site found to date and in July 2012 was inscribed as a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
       UNESCO World Heritage Site
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The settlement of
      <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">
       Troy
      </a>
      started in the Neolithic Age and continued into the
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
       Iron Age
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ancient.eu_44-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ancient.eu-44">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The earliest recorded inhabitants of Anatolia were the
      <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">
       Hattians
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Hurrians" title="Hurrians">
       Hurrians
      </a>
      , non-Indo-European peoples who inhabited central and eastern Anatolia, respectively, as early as ca. 2300 BC. Indo-European
      <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">
       Hittites
      </a>
      came to Anatolia and gradually absorbed the Hattians and Hurrians ca. 2000–1700 BC. The first major empire in the area was founded by the
      <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">
       Hittites
      </a>
      , from the 18th through the 13th century BC. The
      <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">
       Assyrians
      </a>
      conquered and settled parts of southeastern Turkey as early as 1950 BC until the year 612 BC.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
       <a href="#cite_note-46">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">
       Urartu
      </a>
      re-emerged in Assyrian inscriptions in the 9th century BC as a powerful northern rival of Assyria.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Following the collapse of the Hittite empire c. 1180 BC, the
      <a href="/wiki/Phrygia" title="Phrygia">
       Phrygians
      </a>
      , an Indo-European people, achieved ascendancy in Anatolia until their kingdom was destroyed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">
       Cimmerians
      </a>
      in the 7th century BC.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians-48">
        [47]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Starting from 714 BC,
      <a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">
       Urartu
      </a>
      shared the same fate and dissolved in 590 BC,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      when it was conquered by the
      <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">
       Medes
      </a>
      . The most powerful of Phrygia's successor states were
      <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">
       Lydia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Caria" title="Caria">
       Caria
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Lycia" title="Lycia">
       Lycia
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity_and_Byzantine_period">
       Antiquity and Byzantine period
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">
       Classical Anatolia
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Anatolia" title="Byzantine Anatolia">
       Byzantine Anatolia
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
       Byzantine Empire
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">
       Constantinople
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">
       Odrysian kingdom
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7100" data-file-width="9163" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/220px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/330px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/440px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Celsus" title="Library of Celsus">
         Library of Celsus
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">
         Ephesus
        </a>
        was built by the
        <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
         Romans
        </a>
        in 135 AD. The
        <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Artemis" title="Temple of Artemis">
         Temple of Artemis
        </a>
        in Ephesus, built by king
        <a href="/wiki/Croesus" title="Croesus">
         Croesus
        </a>
        of
        <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">
         Lydia
        </a>
        in the 6th century BC, was one of the
        <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">
         Seven Wonders of the Ancient World
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_(2216460729).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2534" data-file-width="3329" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/220px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/330px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/440px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_(2216460729).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Originally a church, later a mosque, and now a museum, the
        <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">
         Hagia Sophia
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
         Istanbul
        </a>
        was built by the
        <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
         Byzantine
        </a>
        emperor
        <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">
         Justinian I
        </a>
        in the 6th century.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Starting around 1200 BC, the coast of
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
       Anatolia
      </a>
      was heavily settled by
      <a href="/wiki/Aeolians" title="Aeolians">
       Aeolian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ionians" title="Ionians">
       Ionian
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">
       Greeks
      </a>
      . Numerous important cities were founded by these colonists, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Miletus" title="Miletus">
       Miletus
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">
       Ephesus
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">
       Smyrna
      </a>
      (now
      <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0zmir" title="İzmir">
       İzmir
      </a>
      ) and
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">
       Byzantium
      </a>
      (now
      <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
       Istanbul
      </a>
      ), the latter founded by
      <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">
       Greek
      </a>
      colonists from
      <a href="/wiki/Megara" title="Megara">
       Megara
      </a>
      in 657 BC. The first state that was called
      <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">
       Armenia
      </a>
      by neighbouring peoples was the state of the
      <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">
       Armenian
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orontid_dynasty" title="Orontid dynasty">
       Orontid dynasty
      </a>
      , which included parts of eastern Turkey beginning in the 6th century BC. In Northwest Turkey, the most significant tribal group in Thrace was the
      <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">
       Odyrisians
      </a>
      , founded by
      <a href="/wiki/Teres_I" title="Teres I">
       Teres I
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LewisBoardman1994_50-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-LewisBoardman1994-50">
        [49]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      All of modern-day Turkey was conquered by the Persian
      <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">
       Achaemenid Empire
      </a>
      during the 6th century BC.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia_51-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia-51">
        [50]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">
       Greco-Persian Wars
      </a>
      started when the Greek city states on the coast of Anatolia rebelled against Persian rule in 499 BC. The territory of Turkey later fell to
      <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">
       Alexander the Great
      </a>
      in 334 BC,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PersiansInAsiaMinor_52-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PersiansInAsiaMinor-52">
        [51]
       </a>
      </sup>
      which led to increasing cultural homogeneity and
      <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">
       Hellenization
      </a>
      in the area.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon2011_15-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon2011-15">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Following Alexander's death in 323 BC, Anatolia was subsequently divided into a number of small
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" title="Hellenistic civilization">
       Hellenistic kingdoms
      </a>
      , all of which became part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">
       Roman Republic
      </a>
      by the mid-1st century BC.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlexanderToRome_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AlexanderToRome-53">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The process of
      <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">
       Hellenization
      </a>
      that began with Alexander's conquest accelerated under Roman rule, and by the early centuries AD the local
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">
       Anatolian languages
      </a>
      and cultures had become extinct, being largely replaced by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language" title="Ancient Greek language">
       ancient Greek language
      </a>
      and culture.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FreedmanMyers2000_17-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FreedmanMyers2000-17">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hout2011_54-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Hout2011-54">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
      From the 1st century BC up to the 3rd century AD, large parts of modern-day Turkey were contested between the
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
       Romans
      </a>
      and neighboring
      <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">
       Parthians
      </a>
      through the frequent
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman-Parthian_Wars" title="Roman-Parthian Wars">
       Roman-Parthian Wars
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In 324,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_I" title="Constantine I">
       Constantine I
      </a>
      chose
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">
       Byzantium
      </a>
      to be the new capital of the
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
       Roman Empire
      </a>
      , renaming it
      <a href="/wiki/New_Rome" title="New Rome">
       New Rome
      </a>
      . Following the death of
      <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">
       Theodosius I
      </a>
      in 395 and the permanent division of the Roman Empire between his two sons, the city, which would popularly come to be known as
      <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">
       Constantinople
      </a>
      , became the capital of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" title="Eastern Roman Empire">
       Eastern Roman Empire
      </a>
      . This, which would later be branded by historians as the
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
       Byzantine Empire
      </a>
      , ruled most of the territory of present-day Turkey until the
      <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">
       Late Middle Ages
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      although the eastern regions remained in firm
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sasanian" title="Sasanian">
       Sasanian
      </a>
      hands up to the first half of the 7th century AD. The frequent
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine-Sassanid_Wars" title="Byzantine-Sassanid Wars">
       Byzantine-Sassanid Wars
      </a>
      , as part of the centuries long-lasting
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman-Persian_Wars" title="Roman-Persian Wars">
       Roman-Persian Wars
      </a>
      , fought between the neighboring rivaling Byzantines and Sasanians, took place in various parts of present-day Turkey and decided much of the latters history from the 4th century AD up to the first half of the 7th century AD.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Seljuks_and_the_Ottoman_Empire">
       Seljuks and the Ottoman Empire
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuk_dynasty" title="Seljuk dynasty">
       Seljuk dynasty
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">
       Ottoman dynasty
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">
       Turkic migration
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">
       Seljuk Empire
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">
       Sultanate of Rum
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2595" data-file-width="3529" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg/220px-Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg/330px-Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg/440px-Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Mevlana_Museum" title="Mevlana Museum">
         Mevlana Museum
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
         Konya
        </a>
        was built by the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuks" title="Seljuks">
         Seljuk Turks
        </a>
        in 1274. Konya was the capital of the Seljuk
        <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">
         Sultanate of Rum
        </a>
        (Anatolia).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turktarihim.com_56-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-turktarihim.com-56">
          [55]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Seljuq_dynasty" title="Seljuq dynasty">
       House of Seljuk
      </a>
      was a branch of the
      <i>
       Kınık
      </i>
      <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">
       Oğuz Turks
      </a>
      who resided on the periphery of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_history#Abbasids_-_.22Islamic_Golden_Age.22" title="Muslim history">
       Muslim world
      </a>
      , in the
      <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Yabgu_State" title="Oghuz Yabgu State">
       Yabgu Khaganate
      </a>
      of the Oğuz confederacy, to the north of the
      <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">
       Caspian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Aral_Sea" title="Aral Sea">
       Aral Seas
      </a>
      , in the 9th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 10th century, the Seljuks started migrating from their ancestral homeland into
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persia" title="Persia">
       Persia
      </a>
      , which became the administrative core of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Seljuq_Empire" title="Great Seljuq Empire">
       Great Seljuk Empire
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-peter.mackenzie.org_58-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-peter.mackenzie.org-58">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the latter half of the 11th century, the Seljuk Turks began penetrating into
      <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Armenia" title="Medieval Armenia">
       medieval Armenia
      </a>
      and the eastern regions of
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
       Anatolia
      </a>
      . In 1071, the Seljuks defeated the Byzantines at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert" title="Battle of Manzikert">
       Battle of Manzikert
      </a>
      , starting the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">
       Turkification
      </a>
      process in the area; the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
       Turkish language
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
       Islam
      </a>
      were introduced to Armenia and Anatolia, gradually spreading throughout the region. The slow transition from a predominantly
      <a href="/wiki/Christian" title="Christian">
       Christian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
       Greek
      </a>
      -speaking Anatolia to a predominantly
      <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">
       Muslim
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
       Turkish
      </a>
      -speaking one was underway.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abazov2009_59-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Abazov2009-59">
        [58]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Alongside the Turkification of the territory, the
      <a href="/wiki/Persianate_society" title="Persianate society">
       culturally Persianized
      </a>
      Seljuks set the basis for a
      <a href="/wiki/Turko-Persian_tradition" title="Turko-Persian tradition">
       Turko-Persian principal culture
      </a>
      in Anatolia,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      which their eventual successors, the Ottomans
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">
       would take over
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        [60]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        [61]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1243, the Seljuk armies were defeated by the
      <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">
       Mongols
      </a>
      , causing the Seljuk Empire's power to slowly disintegrate. In its wake, one of the
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">
       Turkish principalities
      </a>
      governed by
      <a href="/wiki/Osman_I" title="Osman I">
       Osman I
      </a>
      would, over the next 200 years, evolve into the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      . In 1453, the Ottomans completed their conquest of the
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
       Byzantine Empire
      </a>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">
       capturing its capital
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">
       Constantinople
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ottomans_63-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ottomans-63">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1817" data-file-width="3635" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/200px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/300px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/400px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_(cropped).JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="1024" height="83" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG/200px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG/300px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG/400px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="Topkapı Palace">
          Topkapı
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">
          Dolmabahçe
         </a>
         palaces were the primary residences of the
         <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
          Ottoman
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire">
          Sultans
         </a>
         and the administrative center of the empire between 1465 to 1856
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_64-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-nytimes-64">
           [63]
          </a>
         </sup>
         and 1856 to 1922,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dolmabahcepalace_65-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-dolmabahcepalace-65">
           [64]
          </a>
         </sup>
         respectively.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1514, Sultan
      <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">
       Selim I
      </a>
      (1512–1520) successfully expanded the empire's southern and eastern borders by defeating Shah
      <a href="/wiki/Ismail_I" title="Ismail I">
       Ismail I
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">
       Safavid dynasty
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chaldiran" title="Battle of Chaldiran">
       Battle of Chaldiran
      </a>
      . In 1517, Selim I expanded Ottoman rule into
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Algeria" title="Ottoman Algeria">
       Algeria
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Mamluk_War_(1516%E2%80%931517)" title="Ottoman–Mamluk War (1516–1517)">
       Egypt
      </a>
      , and created a naval presence in the
      <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">
       Red Sea
      </a>
      . Subsequently, a competition started between the Ottoman and
      <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">
       Portuguese
      </a>
      empires to become the dominant sea power in the
      <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">
       Indian Ocean
      </a>
      , with
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_naval_expeditions_in_the_Indian_Ocean" title="Ottoman naval expeditions in the Indian Ocean">
       a number of naval battles
      </a>
      in the Red Sea, the
      <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">
       Arabian Sea
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">
       Persian Gulf
      </a>
      . The Portuguese presence in the Indian Ocean was perceived as a threat for the Ottoman monopoly over the ancient trade routes between
      <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">
       East Asia
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">
       Western Europe
      </a>
      . Despite the increasingly prominent European presence, the Ottoman Empire's trade with the east continued to flourish until the second half of the 18th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Ottoman Empire's power and prestige peaked in the 16th and 17th centuries, particularly during the reign of
      <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">
       Suleiman the Magnificent
      </a>
      , who personally instituted major legislative changes relating to society, education, taxation and criminal law. The empire was often at odds with the
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">
       Holy Roman Empire
      </a>
      in its steady advance towards
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
       Central Europe
      </a>
      through the
      <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
       Balkans
      </a>
      and the southern part of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth">
       Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_67-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-67">
        [66]
       </a>
      </sup>
      At sea, the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Navy" title="Ottoman Navy">
       Ottoman Navy
      </a>
      contended with several Holy Leagues, such as those in
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1538)" title="Holy League (1538)">
       1538
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1571)" title="Holy League (1571)">
       1571
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">
       1684
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1717)" title="Holy League (1717)">
       1717
      </a>
      (composed primarily of
      <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Spain" title="Habsburg Spain">
       Habsburg Spain
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">
       Republic of Genoa
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
       Republic of Venice
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
       Knights of St. John
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">
       Papal States
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Tuscany" title="Grand Duchy of Tuscany">
       Grand Duchy of Tuscany
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Savoy" title="Duchy of Savoy">
       Duchy of Savoy
      </a>
      ), for the control of the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
       Mediterranean Sea
      </a>
      . In the east, the Ottomans were often at war with
      <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">
       Safavid Persia
      </a>
      over conflicts stemming from territorial disputes or religious differences between the 16th and 18th centuries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        [67]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman-Persian_Wars" title="Ottoman-Persian Wars">
       Ottoman wars with Persia
      </a>
      continued as the
      <a href="/wiki/Zand_dynasty" title="Zand dynasty">
       Zand
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty" title="Afsharid dynasty">
       Afsharid
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">
       Qajar
      </a>
      dynasties succeeded the Safavids in Iran, until the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman-Persian_War_(1821-1823)" title="Ottoman-Persian War (1821-1823)">
       first half of the 19th century
      </a>
      . From the 16th to the early 20th centuries, the Ottoman Empire also
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_Wars" title="Russo-Turkish Wars">
       fought many wars
      </a>
      with the
      <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">
       Russian Tsardom
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
       Empire
      </a>
      . These were initially about the Ottoman territorial expansion and consolidation in southeastern and eastern Europe; but starting from the
      <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1768%E2%80%9374)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1768–74)">
       latter half of the 18th century
      </a>
      , they became more about the survival of the Ottoman state, which began to lose its strategic territories on the northern
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
       Black Sea
      </a>
      coast to the advancing Russians. Between the 18th and the early 20th centuries, the Ottoman, Persian and Russian empires were neighbouring rivals of each other.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OttomanEmpire1683.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2582" data-file-width="3596" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/28/OttomanEmpire1683.png/220px-OttomanEmpire1683.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/28/OttomanEmpire1683.png/330px-OttomanEmpire1683.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/28/OttomanEmpire1683.png/440px-OttomanEmpire1683.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:OttomanEmpire1683.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
         Ottoman Empire
        </a>
        's territorial extent in Europe, Asia and Africa at the time of the
        <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">
         second Turkish siege of Vienna
        </a>
        in 1683, which marked the start of the
        <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">
         Great Turkish War
        </a>
        (1683–1699).
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      From the second half of the 18th century onwards, the Ottoman Empire
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">
       began to decline
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
       Tanzimat
      </a>
      reforms of the 19th century aimed to modernize the Ottoman state in line with the progress that was made in the West, but these efforts proved to be inadequate in most fields, and failed to stop the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Dissolution of the Ottoman Empire">
       dissolution of the empire
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OttoTurkVis_20-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-OttoTurkVis-20">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As it gradually shrank in size, military power and wealth, especially after the
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Eastern_Crisis_(1875%E2%80%9378)" title="Great Eastern Crisis (1875–78)">
       Ottoman economic crisis and default in 1875
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NiallFergusonFT_69-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NiallFergusonFT-69">
        [68]
       </a>
      </sup>
      which led to uprisings in the Balkan provinces that culminated into the
      <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%9378)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–78)">
       Russo-Turkish War of 1877–78
      </a>
      , many Balkan Muslims migrated to the Empire's heartland in Anatolia,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Illinois2009_70-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Illinois2009-70">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
       <a href="#cite_note-71">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
      along with the
      <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">
       Circassians
      </a>
      fleeing the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian%E2%80%93Circassian_War" title="Russian–Circassian War">
       Russian conquest
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Russian_conquest_of_the_Caucasus" title="Russian conquest of the Caucasus">
       Caucasus
      </a>
      . The decline of the Ottoman Empire led to a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rise_of_nationalism_under_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of nationalism under the Ottoman Empire">
       rise in nationalist sentiment among the various subject peoples
      </a>
      , leading to increased ethnic tensions which occasionally burst into violence, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Hamidian_massacres" title="Hamidian massacres">
       Hamidian massacres
      </a>
      of Armenians.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nzhistory.net.nz_72-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nzhistory.net.nz-72">
        [71]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution" title="Young Turk Revolution">
       Young Turk Revolution
      </a>
      in 1908
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Constitutional_Era" title="Second Constitutional Era">
       restored
      </a>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">
       Ottoman constitution
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="General Assembly of the Ottoman Empire">
       parliament
      </a>
      30 years after their
      <a href="/wiki/First_Constitutional_Era" title="First Constitutional Era">
       suspension
      </a>
      by Sultan
      <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hamid_II" title="Abdul Hamid II">
       Abdülhamid II
      </a>
      in 1878, but the
      <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'état">
       1913 Ottoman coup d'état
      </a>
      effectively put the country under the control of the
      <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">
       Three Pashas
      </a>
      . This made sultans
      <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">
       Mehmed V
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_VI" title="Mehmed VI">
       Mehmed VI
      </a>
      largely symbolic figureheads with no real political power.
     </p>
     <p>
      The Ottoman Empire entered
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
       World War I
      </a>
      on the side of the
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">
       Central Powers
      </a>
      and was ultimately defeated. During the war, the empire's
      <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">
       Armenians
      </a>
      were
      <a href="/wiki/Tehcir_Law" title="Tehcir Law">
       deported
      </a>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">
       Syria
      </a>
      as part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" title="Armenian Genocide">
       Armenian Genocide
      </a>
      . As a result, an estimated 800,000 to 1,500,000 Armenians were killed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        [73]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        [74]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        [75]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Turkish government has
      <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide_denial" title="Armenian Genocide denial">
       refused to acknowledge
      </a>
      the events as
      <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">
       genocide
      </a>
      and claims that Armenians were only
      <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer" title="Population transfer">
       relocated
      </a>
      from the eastern war zone.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Large-scale massacres were also committed against the empire's other minority groups such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" title="Assyrian genocide">
       Assyrians
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">
       Greeks
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloxham2005_78-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bloxham2005-78">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Levene_79-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Levene-79">
        [78]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ferguson_80-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ferguson-80">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following the
      <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">
       Armistice of Mudros
      </a>
      on 30 October 1918, the victorious
      <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">
       Allied Powers
      </a>
      sought to
      <a href="/wiki/Partitioning_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partitioning of the Ottoman Empire">
       partition the Ottoman state
      </a>
      through the 1920
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">
       Treaty of Sèvres
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ottomans_63-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ottomans-63">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_Turkey">
       Republic of Turkey
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="History of the Republic of Turkey">
       History of the Republic of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
       Atatürk's Reforms
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="655" data-file-width="904" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg/250px-Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg/375px-Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg/500px-Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_at_Cankaya_Library_16_July_1929.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
         Mustafa Kemal Atatürk
        </a>
        , founder and first President of the Turkish Republic, at the library of Çankaya Mansion in
        <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">
         Ankara
        </a>
        , 1929.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Constantinople" title="Occupation of Constantinople">
       occupation of Istanbul
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Smyrna" title="Occupation of Smyrna">
       Izmir
      </a>
      by the Allies in the aftermath of World War I prompted the establishment of the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_National_Movement" title="Turkish National Movement">
       Turkish National Movement
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19may_81-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-19may-81">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Under the leadership of
      <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
       Mustafa Kemal
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Pasha" title="Pasha">
       Pasha
      </a>
      , a military commander who had distinguished himself during the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gallipoli" title="Battle of Gallipoli">
       Battle of Gallipoli
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">
       Turkish War of Independence
      </a>
      was waged with the aim of revoking the terms of the Treaty of Sèvres.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atat.C3.BCrk_82-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Atat.C3.BCrk-82">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      By 18 September 1922 the occupying armies were expelled,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18sep1922_83-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-18sep1922-83">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Provisional_Government" title="Turkish Provisional Government">
       Ankara-based Turkish regime
      </a>
      , which had declared itself the legitimate government of the country on
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">
       23 April 1920
      </a>
      , started to formalize the legal transition from the old Ottoman into the new Republican political system. On 1 November 1922, the
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">
       Turkish Parliament
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">
       Ankara
      </a>
      formally
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_Sultanate" title="Abolition of the Ottoman Sultanate">
       abolished the Sultanate
      </a>
      , thus ending 623 years of monarchical Ottoman rule. The
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">
       Treaty of Lausanne
      </a>
      of 24 July 1923 led to the international recognition of the sovereignty of the newly formed "Republic of Turkey" as the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, and the republic was officially proclaimed on 29 October 1923 in Ankara, the country's new capital.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Lausanne treaty stipulated a
      <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">
       population exchange between Greece and Turkey
      </a>
      , whereby 1.1 million Greeks left Turkey for Greece in exchange for 380,000 Muslims transferred from Greece to Turkey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clogg_85-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Clogg-85">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Mustafa Kemal became the republic's first
      <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">
       President
      </a>
      and subsequently introduced
      <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
       many radical reforms
      </a>
      with the aim of transforming the old
      <a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">
       religion-based and multi-communal
      </a>
      Ottoman state system (
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">
       constitutional
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">
       monarchy
      </a>
      ) into an essentially Turkish
      <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">
       nation state
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
       parliamentary republic
      </a>
      ) with a
      <a href="/wiki/La%C3%AFcit%C3%A9" title="Laïcité">
       secular
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution_of_1924" title="Turkish Constitution of 1924">
       constitution
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoweringCrone2012_86-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BoweringCrone2012-86">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With the
      <a href="/wiki/Surname_Law" title="Surname Law">
       Surname Law
      </a>
      of 1934, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Parliament" title="Turkish Parliament">
       Turkish Parliament
      </a>
      bestowed upon Mustafa Kemal the honorific surname "Atatürk" (
      <i>
       Father of the Turks
      </i>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atat.C3.BCrk_82-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Atat.C3.BCrk-82">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="435" data-file-width="487" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/44/Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg/220px-Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/44/Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg/330px-Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/44/Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg/440px-Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_attends_a_university_class.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
         Atatürk
        </a>
        joins a Law class at the
        <i>
         İstanbul Darülfünûnu
        </i>
        on December 15, 1930, which he later
        <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
         reformed
        </a>
        as the
        <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">
         Istanbul University
        </a>
        on August 1, 1933.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Cairo_Conference" title="Second Cairo Conference">
       remained neutral
      </a>
      during most of
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      , but entered the closing stages of the war on the side of the
      <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">
       Allies
      </a>
      on 23 February 1945. On 26 June 1945, Turkey became a
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">
       charter member
      </a>
      of the United Nations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turkey_UN_87-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Turkey_UN-87">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Difficulties faced by Greece after the war in quelling a
      <a href="/wiki/Greek_Civil_War" title="Greek Civil War">
       communist rebellion
      </a>
      , along with demands by the
      <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
       Soviet Union
      </a>
      for military bases in the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Straits" title="Turkish Straits">
       Turkish Straits
      </a>
      , prompted the United States to declare the
      <a href="/wiki/Truman_Doctrine" title="Truman Doctrine">
       Truman Doctrine
      </a>
      in 1947. The doctrine enunciated American intentions to guarantee the security of Turkey and Greece, and resulted in large-scale
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkey-United_States_relations" title="Turkey-United States relations">
       U.S. military and economic support
      </a>
      . Both countries were included in the
      <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">
       Marshall Plan
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_European_Economic_Co-operation" title="Organisation for European Economic Co-operation">
       OEEC
      </a>
      for rebuilding European economies in 1948,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Truman_Doctrine_88-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Truman_Doctrine-88">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and subsequently became founding members of the
      <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
       OECD
      </a>
      in 1961.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd.org_89-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-oecd.org-89">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      After participating with the United Nations forces in the
      <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">
       Korean War
      </a>
      , Turkey joined
      <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
       NATO
      </a>
      in 1952, becoming a bulwark against Soviet expansion into the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">
       Mediterranean
      </a>
      . Following a decade of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cypriot_intercommunal_violence" title="Cypriot intercommunal violence">
       Cypriot intercommunal violence
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/1974_Cypriot_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1974 Cypriot coup d'état">
       coup in Cyprus on 15 July 1974
      </a>
      staged by the
      <a href="/wiki/EOKA_B" title="EOKA B">
       EOKA B
      </a>
      paramilitary organization, which overthrew President
      <a href="/wiki/Makarios_III" title="Makarios III">
       Makarios
      </a>
      and installed the pro-
      <a href="/wiki/Enosis" title="Enosis">
       Enosis
      </a>
      (union with Greece)
      <a href="/wiki/Nikos_Sampson" title="Nikos Sampson">
       Nikos Sampson
      </a>
      as dictator,
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_invasion_of_Cyprus" title="Turkish invasion of Cyprus">
       Turkey invaded Cyprus
      </a>
      on 20 July 1974.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Uslu2003_90-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Uslu2003-90">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Nine years later the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Republic_of_Northern_Cyprus" title="Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus">
       Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus
      </a>
      , which is recognized only by Turkey, was established.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Single-Party_Period_of_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Single-Party Period of Republic of Turkey">
       single-party period
      </a>
      ended in 1945. It was followed by a tumultuous transition to
      <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">
       multiparty democracy
      </a>
      over the next few decades, which was interrupted by military
      <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">
       coups d'état
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/1960_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1960 Turkish coup d'état">
       1960
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1971_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1971 Turkish coup d'état">
       1971
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/1980_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1980 Turkish coup d'état">
       1980
      </a>
      , as well as a military memorandum in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1997_military_memorandum_(Turkey)" title="1997 military memorandum (Turkey)">
       1997
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRPoliticsandMilitary_92-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TRPoliticsandMilitary-92">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1984, the
      <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Workers%27_Party" title="Kurdistan Workers' Party">
       PKK
      </a>
      , a Kurdish separatist group, began an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kurdish%E2%80%93Turkish_conflict" title="Kurdish–Turkish conflict">
       insurgency campaign
      </a>
      against the Turkish government. The Kurdish-Turkish conflict to date has claimed over 40,000 lives.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Over 3,000 Kurdish villages were burned by Turkish security forces and hundreds of thousands of Kurds displaced,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hrw_95-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hrw-95">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and Kurdish political parties were banned.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bahar_96-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bahar-96">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Solution_process" title="Solution process">
       Peace talks
      </a>
      were launched in 2012,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but
      <a href="/wiki/Kurdish%E2%80%93Turkish_conflict_(2015%E2%80%93present)" title="Kurdish–Turkish conflict (2015–present)">
       hostilities
      </a>
      restarted in 2015 following the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suruc_bombing" title="Suruc bombing">
       Suruc bombing
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the liberalization of the Turkish economy during the 1980s, the country has enjoyed stronger economic growth and greater political stability.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80sLiberalization_100-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-80sLiberalization-100">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2013,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Turkey" title="2013 protests in Turkey">
       widespread protests
      </a>
      erupted in many Turkish provinces, sparked by a plan to demolish
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gezi_Park" title="Gezi Park">
       Gezi Park
      </a>
      but growing into general anti-government dissent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
       <a href="#cite_note-101">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On 15–16 July 2016, an
      <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt">
       unsuccessful coup attempt
      </a>
      tried to oust the government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
       <a href="#cite_note-102">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
       Administrative divisions
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Turkey" title="Administrative divisions of Turkey">
       Administrative divisions of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions_of_Turkey" title="Regions of Turkey">
       Regions of Turkey
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Turkey" title="NUTS of Turkey">
       NUTS of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey has a unitary structure in terms of administration and this aspect is one of the most important factors shaping the Turkish public administration. When three powers (executive, legislative and judiciary) are taken into account as the main functions of the state, local administrations have little power. Turkey is a unitary not a federal system, and the provinces are subordinated to the centre. Local administrations were established to provide services in place and the government is represented by the governors and city governors. Besides the governors and the city governors, other senior public officials are also appointed by the central government rather than appointed by mayors or elected by constituents.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-justice.gov.tr_103-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-justice.gov.tr-103">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey is subdivided into 81
      <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">
       provinces
      </a>
      for administrative purposes. Each province is divided into
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Districts_of_Turkey" title="Districts of Turkey">
       districts
      </a>
      , for a total of 923 districts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
       <a href="#cite_note-104">
        [103]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey is also subdivided into 7
      <a href="/wiki/Geographical_regions_of_Turkey" title="Geographical regions of Turkey">
       regions
      </a>
      and 21 subregions for geographic, demographic and economic purposes; this does not refer to an administrative division.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7regions_105-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-7regions-105">
        [104]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <center>
      <div role="img" style="width: 700px; float: none; clear: none; font-size: 85%; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;">

     </center>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
       Politics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Turkey" title="Politics of Turkey">
       Politics of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">
       Constitution of Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Turkey" title="Elections in Turkey">
       Elections in Turkey
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Ministries_of_Turkey" title="Ministries of Turkey">
       Ministries of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:right; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;">
      <tr>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG">
         <img alt="Recep Tayyip Erdogan.PNG" data-file-height="488" data-file-width="370" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/121px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/182px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/242px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG 2x" width="121"/>
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg">
         <img alt="Binali Yıldırım.jpg" data-file-height="369" data-file-width="276" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg/120px-Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg/180px-Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg/240px-Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td style="text-align:center;">
        <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">
         Tayyip Erdoğan
        </a>
        <br/>
        <small>
         <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">
          President
         </a>
        </small>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:center;">
        <a href="/wiki/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m" title="Binali Yıldırım">
         Binali Yıldırım
        </a>
        <br/>
        <small>
         <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Turkey" title="Prime Minister of Turkey">
          Prime Minister
         </a>
        </small>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      Turkey is a
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
       parliamentary
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">
       representative democracy
      </a>
      . Since its foundation as a republic in 1923, Turkey
      <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">
       has developed a strong tradition
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">
       secularism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_Secularism_106-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TR_Secularism-106">
        [105]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">
       Turkey's constitution
      </a>
      governs the legal framework of the country. It sets out the main principles of government and establishes Turkey as a unitary centralized state. The
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Turkey" title="List of Presidents of Turkey">
       President of the Republic
      </a>
      is the
      <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
       head of state
      </a>
      and has a largely ceremonial role. The president is elected for a five-year term by direct elections and
      <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">
       Tayyip Erdoğan
      </a>
      is the first president elected by direct voting.
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">
       Executive power
      </a>
      is exercised by the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Turkey" title="List of Prime Ministers of Turkey">
       Prime Minister
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Turkey" title="Council of Ministers of Turkey">
       Council of Ministers
      </a>
      which make up the government, while the
      <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">
       legislative
