      </a>
      power is vested in the unicameral parliament, the
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">
       Grand National Assembly of Turkey
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">
       judiciary
      </a>
      is independent of the executive and the legislature, and the Constitutional Court is charged with ruling on the conformity of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_System_in_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Legal System in the Republic of Turkey">
       laws and decrees
      </a>
      with the constitution. The
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Council_of_State" title="Turkish Council of State">
       Council of State
      </a>
      is the tribunal of last resort for administrative cases, and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Appeals_of_Turkey" title="High Court of Appeals of Turkey">
       High Court of Appeals
      </a>
      for all others.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_Constit_107-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TR_Constit-107">
        [106]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The prime minister is elected by the parliament through a vote of confidence in the government and is most often the head of the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Turkey" title="List of political parties in Turkey">
       party
      </a>
      having the most seats in parliament. The prime minister is
      <a href="/wiki/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m" title="Binali Yıldırım">
       Binali Yıldırım
      </a>
      , who replaced
      <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Davuto%C4%9Flu" title="Ahmet Davutoğlu">
       Ahmet Davutoğlu
      </a>
      on 24 May 2016.
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">
       Universal suffrage
      </a>
      for both sexes has been applied throughout Turkey since 1933, and every Turkish citizen who has turned 18 years of age has the right to vote. There are 550
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" title="Member of Parliament">
       members of parliament
      </a>
      who are elected for a four-year term by a
      <a href="/wiki/Party-list_proportional_representation" title="Party-list proportional representation">
       party-list proportional representation
      </a>
      system from 85 electoral districts. The Constitutional Court can strip the public financing of
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Turkey" title="List of political parties in Turkey">
       political parties
      </a>
      that it deems
      <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">
       anti-secular
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Separatism" title="Separatism">
       separatist
      </a>
      , or ban their existence altogether.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
       <a href="#cite_note-108">
        [107]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        [108]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electoral_threshold" title="Electoral threshold">
       electoral threshold
      </a>
      is 10 percent of the votes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BYEGM_TrPolSys_110-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BYEGM_TrPolSys-110">
        [109]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Supporters of
      <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
       Atatürk's reforms
      </a>
      are called
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kemalist" title="Kemalist">
       Kemalists
      </a>
      , as distinguished from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamist" title="Islamist">
       Islamists
      </a>
      , representing two extremes on a continuum of beliefs about the proper role of religion in public life.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_111-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-111">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Kemalist position generally combines a kind of
      <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">
       democracy
      </a>
      with a
      <a href="/wiki/La%C3%AFcit%C3%A9" title="Laïcité">
       laicist
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">
       constitution
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">
       westernised
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">
       secular
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Lifestyle_(sociology)" title="Lifestyle (sociology)">
       lifestyle
      </a>
      , while supporting
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_intervention" title="State intervention">
       state intervention
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Economy" title="Economy">
       economy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Education" title="Education">
       education
      </a>
      , and other
      <a href="/wiki/Public_service" title="Public service">
       public services
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_111-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-111">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the 1980s, a rise in income inequality and class distinction has given rise to
      <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">
       Islamic populism
      </a>
      , a movement that in theory supports obligation to authority, communal solidarity and social justice, though what that entails in practice is often contested.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_111-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-111">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">
       Human rights
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">
       Human rights in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg/260px-Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg/390px-Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg/520px-Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg 2x" width="260"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ankara_K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Meydan%C4%B1%27nda_Gezi_protestosu.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A view from the
        <a href="/wiki/Gezi_Park_protests" title="Gezi Park protests">
         Gezi Park protests
        </a>
        in 2013,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lay_Square" title="Kızılay Square">
         Kızılay Square
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">
         Ankara
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">
       Human rights in Turkey
      </a>
      have been the subject of some controversy and international condemnation. Between 1998 and 2008 the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">
       European Court of Human Rights
      </a>
      made more than 1,600 judgements against Turkey for human rights violations, particularly regarding the right to life, and freedom from torture. Other issues, such as Kurdish rights, women's rights, LGBT rights, and press freedom, have also attracted controversy. Turkey's human rights record continues to be a significant obstacle to future membership of the EU.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        [111]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to the
      <a href="/wiki/Committee_to_Protect_Journalists" title="Committee to Protect Journalists">
       Committee to Protect Journalists
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">
       AKP
      </a>
      government has waged one of the world's biggest crackdowns on press freedoms.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPJ_113-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CPJ-113">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A large number of journalists have been arrested using charges of "terrorism" and "anti-state activities" such as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ergenekon_(organization)" title="Ergenekon (organization)">
       Ergenekon
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sledgehammer_(coup_plan)" title="Sledgehammer (coup plan)">
       Balyoz
      </a>
      cases, while thousands have been investigated on charges such as "denigrating Turkishness" or "insulting Islam" in an effort to sow self-censorship.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPJ_113-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-CPJ-113">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2012, the CPJ identified 76 jailed journalists in Turkey, including 61 directly held for their published work, ranking 1st in the world, more than in Iran, Eritrea or China
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPJ_113-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-CPJ-113">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freemuse" title="Freemuse">
       Freemuse
      </a>
      identified 9 musicians imprisoned for their work, ranking 3rd after Russia and China.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freemuse_114-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-freemuse-114">
        [113]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A former
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">
       U.S. State Department
      </a>
      spokesman,
      <a href="/wiki/Philip_J._Crowley" title="Philip J. Crowley">
       Philip J. Crowley
      </a>
      , said that the United States had "broad concerns about trends involving intimidation of journalists in Turkey."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
       <a href="#cite_note-115">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey has a 'Not Free'
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press_(report)" title="Freedom of the Press (report)">
       rating by
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
       Freedom House
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_116-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-116">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In its resolution "The functioning of democratic institutions in Turkey" on 22 June 2016, the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_Assembly_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe">
       Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe
      </a>
      warned that "recent developments in Turkey pertaining to freedom of the media and of expression, erosion of the rule of law and the human rights violations in relation to anti-terrorism security operations in south-east Turkey have (...) raised serious questions about the functioning of its democratic institutions."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        [116]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Law">
       Law
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Turkey" title="Judicial system of Turkey">
       Judicial system of Turkey
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Turkey" title="Law enforcement in Turkey">
       Law enforcement in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey has a legal system which has been wholly integrated with the system of continental Europe. For instance, the Turkish Civil Law has been modified by incorporating elements mainly of the Swiss Civil Code, the Code of Obligations and the German Commercial Code. The Administrative Law bears similarities with its French counterpart, and the Penal Code with its Italian counterpart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mymerhaba.com_118-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mymerhaba.com-118">
        [117]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey has adopted the principle of the
      <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">
       separation of powers
      </a>
      . In line with this principle, judicial power is exercised by independent courts on behalf of the Turkish nation. The independence and organization of the courts, the security of the tenure of judges and public prosecutors, the profession of judges and prosecutors, the supervision of judges and public prosecutors, the military courts and their organization, and the powers and duties of the high courts are regulated by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">
       Turkish Constitution
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_119-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-119">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      According to Article 142 of the Turkish Constitution, the organization, duties and jurisdiction of the courts, their functions and the trial procedures are regulated by law. In line with the aforementioned article of the Turkish Constitution and related laws, the court system in Turkey can be classified under three main categories; which are the Judicial Courts, Administrative Courts and Military Courts. Each category includes first instance courts and high courts. In addition, the Court of Jurisdictional Disputes rules on cases that cannot be classified readily as falling within the purview of one court system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_119-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-119">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Law enforcement in Turkey is carried out by several departments (such as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Directorate_of_Security" title="General Directorate of Security">
       General Directorate of Security
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gendarmerie_General_Command" title="Gendarmerie General Command">
       Gendarmerie General Command
      </a>
      ) and agencies, all acting under the command of the
      <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Turkey" title="Prime Minister of Turkey">
       Prime Minister of Turkey
      </a>
      or mostly the
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)">
       Minister of Internal Affairs
      </a>
      . According to figures released by the
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Justice (Turkey)">
       Justice Ministry
      </a>
      , there are 100,000 people in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_prisons" title="Turkish prisons">
       Turkish prisons
      </a>
      as of November 2008, a doubling since 2000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the years of government by the
      <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">
       AKP
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">
       Tayyip Erdoğan
      </a>
      , particularly since 2013, the independence and integrity of the Turkish judiciary has increasingly been considered in doubt by institutions, parliamentarians and journalists both within and outside of Turkey; due to political interference in the promotion of judges and prosecutors, and in their pursuit of public duty.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU2015_121-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EU2015-121">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EP2016_122-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EP2016-122">
        [121]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TI2016_123-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TI2016-123">
        [122]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        [123]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <i>
       Turkey 2015 report
      </i>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">
       European Commission
      </a>
      stated that "the independence of the judiciary and respect of the principle of separation of powers have been undermined and judges and prosecutors have been under strong political pressure."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU2015_121-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EU2015-121">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
       Foreign relations
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Turkey" title="Foreign relations of Turkey">
       Foreign relations of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1200" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/220px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/330px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/440px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        After becoming
        <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">
         one of the first members
        </a>
        of the
        <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
         Council of Europe
        </a>
        in 1949, Turkey became an
        <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">
         associate member
        </a>
        of the
        <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">
         EEC
        </a>
        in 1963, joined the
        <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">
         EU Customs Union
        </a>
        in 1995 and started
        <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">
         full membership negotiations
        </a>
        with the
        <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
         European Union
        </a>
        in 2005.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_26-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-26">
          [25]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg/220px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg/330px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg/440px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_in_Turkey.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Leaders of the
        <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">
         G-20
        </a>
        at the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2015_G-20_Antalya_summit" title="2015 G-20 Antalya summit">
         2015 Antalya summit
        </a>
        in Turkey.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey is a founding member of the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
       United Nations
      </a>
      (1945),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign3_125-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign3-125">
        [124]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
       OECD
      </a>
      (1961),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign1_126-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign1-126">
        [125]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">
       OIC
      </a>
      (1969),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign4_127-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign4-127">
        [126]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
       OSCE
      </a>
      (1973),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign5_128-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign5-128">
        [127]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">
       ECO
      </a>
      (1985),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign6_129-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign6-129">
        [128]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">
       BSEC
      </a>
      (1992),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign7_130-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign7-130">
        [129]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developing_8_Countries" title="Developing 8 Countries">
       D-8
      </a>
      (1997)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign8_131-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign8-131">
        [130]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">
       G-20
      </a>
      (1999).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign2_132-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign2-132">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey was a member of the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">
       United Nations Security Council
      </a>
      in 1951–1952, 1954–1955, 1961 and 2009–2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-H.C3.BCrriyet_UN_Security_133-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-H.C3.BCrriyet_UN_Security-133">
        [132]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In September 2013, Turkey became a member of the
      <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cooperation_Dialogue" title="Asia Cooperation Dialogue">
       Asia Cooperation Dialogue
      </a>
      (ACD).
     </p>
     <p>
      In line with its traditional Western orientation, relations with Europe have always been a central part of Turkish foreign policy. Turkey became
      <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">
       one of the first members
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
       Council of Europe
      </a>
      in 1949, applied for associate membership of the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">
       EEC
      </a>
      (predecessor of the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
       European Union
      </a>
      ) in 1959 and became an
      <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">
       associate member
      </a>
      in 1963. After decades of political negotiations, Turkey applied for full membership of the EEC in 1987, became an associate member of the
      <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union" title="Western European Union">
       Western European Union
      </a>
      in 1992, joined the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">
       EU Customs Union
      </a>
      in 1995 and has been in
      <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">
       formal accession negotiations
      </a>
      with the EU since 2005.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_26-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-26">
        [25]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Today, EU membership is considered as a state policy and a strategic target by Turkey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        [133]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey's support for
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cyprus" title="Northern Cyprus">
       Northern Cyprus
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">
       Cyprus dispute
      </a>
      complicates Turkey's relations with the EU and remains a major stumbling block to the country's
      <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">
       EU accession bid.
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mardell_135-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mardell-135">
        [134]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The other defining aspect of Turkey's foreign policy was the country's long-standing strategic alliance with the United States.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-foreignaffairs.com_136-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-foreignaffairs.com-136">
        [135]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fas.org_137-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fas.org-137">
        [136]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The common threat posed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
       Soviet Union
      </a>
      during the
      <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
       Cold War
      </a>
      led to Turkey's membership of
      <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
       NATO
      </a>
      in 1952, ensuring close bilateral relations with
      <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">
       Washington
      </a>
      . Subsequently Turkey benefited from the United States' political, economic and diplomatic support, including in key issues such as the country's bid to join the European Union.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the post–Cold War environment, Turkey's geostrategic importance shifted towards its proximity to the
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">
       Middle East
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">
       Caucasus
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
       Balkans
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edoc.hu-berlin.de_139-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-edoc.hu-berlin.de-139">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The independence of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkic_states" title="Turkic states">
       Turkic states
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
       Soviet Union
      </a>
      in 1991, with which Turkey shares a common cultural and linguistic heritage, allowed Turkey to extend its economic and political relations deep into
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">
       Central Asia
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bal2004_140-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bal2004-140">
        [139]
       </a>
      </sup>
      thus enabling the completion of a multi-billion-dollar oil and natural gas
      <a href="/wiki/Pipeline_transport" title="Pipeline transport">
       pipeline
      </a>
      from
      <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">
       Baku
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">
       Azerbaijan
      </a>
      to the port of
      <a href="/wiki/Ceyhan" title="Ceyhan">
       Ceyhan
      </a>
      in Turkey. The
      <a href="/wiki/Baku%E2%80%93Tbilisi%E2%80%93Ceyhan_pipeline" title="Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline">
       Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline
      </a>
      forms part of Turkey's foreign policy strategy to become an energy conduit to the West. However Turkey's border with
      <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">
       Armenia
      </a>
      , a state in the
      <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">
       Caucasus
      </a>
      , was closed by Turkey in support of
      <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">
       Azerbaijan
      </a>
      during the
      <a href="/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh_War" title="Nagorno-Karabakh War">
       Nagorno-Karabakh War
      </a>
      and remains closed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        [140]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Under the
      <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">
       AKP
      </a>
      government, Turkey's influence has grown in the formerly
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman
      </a>
      territories of the
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">
       Middle East
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
       Balkans
      </a>
      , based on the "strategic depth" doctrine (a terminology that was coined by
      <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Davuto%C4%9Flu" title="Ahmet Davutoğlu">
       Ahmet Davutoğlu
      </a>
      for defining Turkey's increased engagement in regional foreign policy issues), also called
      <a href="/wiki/Neo-Ottomanism" title="Neo-Ottomanism">
       Neo-Ottomanism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
       <a href="#cite_note-142">
        [141]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        [142]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following the
      <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">
       Arab Spring
      </a>
      in December 2010, the choices made by the AKP government for supporting certain political opposition groups in the affected countries have led to tensions with some Arab states, such as Turkey's neighbour
      <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">
       Syria
      </a>
      since the start of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian_civil_war" title="Syrian civil war">
       Syrian civil war
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">
       Egypt
      </a>
      after the
      <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="2013 Egyptian coup d'état">
       ousting of President Mohamed Morsi
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        [143]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , Turkey doesn't have an
      <a href="/wiki/Ambassador" title="Ambassador">
       ambassador
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">
       Syria
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">
       Egypt
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
       <a href="#cite_note-146">
        [145]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
       <a href="#cite_note-147">
        [146]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Diplomatic relations with Israel were also severed after the
      <a href="/wiki/Gaza_flotilla_raid" title="Gaza flotilla raid">
       Gaza flotilla raid
      </a>
      in 2010, but were normalized following a deal in June 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
       <a href="#cite_note-148">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
      These political rifts have left Turkey with few allies in the
      <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">
       East Mediterranean
      </a>
      , where rich
      <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">
       natural gas
      </a>
      fields have recently been discovered;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
       <a href="#cite_note-149">
        [148]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
       <a href="#cite_note-150">
        [149]
       </a>
      </sup>
      in sharp contrast with the original goals that were set by the former Foreign Minister (later Prime Minister)
      <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Davuto%C4%9Flu" title="Ahmet Davutoğlu">
       Ahmet Davutoğlu
      </a>
      in his "zero problems with neighbours"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
       <a href="#cite_note-151">
        [150]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        [151]
       </a>
      </sup>
      foreign policy doctrine.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
       <a href="#cite_note-153">
        [152]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2015, Turkey,
      <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">
       Saudi Arabia
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">
       Qatar
      </a>
      formed a "strategic alliance" against Syrian President
      <a href="/wiki/Bashar_al-Assad" title="Bashar al-Assad">
       Bashar al-Assad
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
       <a href="#cite_note-154">
        [153]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        [154]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey has maintained forces in international missions under the United Nations and NATO since 1950, including
      <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">
       peacekeeping
      </a>
      missions in
      <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">
       Somalia
      </a>
      and former
      <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">
       Yugoslavia
      </a>
      , and support to coalition forces in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Gulf_War" title="First Gulf War">
       First Gulf War
      </a>
      . Turkey maintains 36,000 troops in
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cyprus" title="Northern Cyprus">
       Northern Cyprus
      </a>
      , though their presence is controversial,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Richmond1998_156-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Richmond1998-156">
        [155]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and assists
      <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_Kurdistan" title="Iraqi Kurdistan">
       Iraqi Kurdistan
      </a>
      with security.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
       <a href="#cite_note-157">
        [156]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey has had troops deployed in
      <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
       Afghanistan
      </a>
      as part of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present)">
       United States stabilization force
      </a>
      and the UN-authorized, NATO-commanded
      <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">
       International Security Assistance Force
      </a>
      (ISAF) since 2001.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tskpeace_158-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-tskpeace-158">
        [157]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since 2003, Turkey contributes military personnel to
      <a href="/wiki/Eurocorps" title="Eurocorps">
       Eurocorps
      </a>
      and takes part in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Union_battlegroups#Contributions" title="European Union battlegroups">
       EU Battlegroups
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enter_the_EU_Battle_Groups_159-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Enter_the_EU_Battle_Groups-159">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
       Military
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">
       Turkish Armed Forces
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Turkey" title="Defense industry of Turkey">
       Defense industry of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2037" data-file-width="3683" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg/220px-NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg/330px-NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg/440px-NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NATO_Ministers_of_Defense_and_of_Foreign_Affairs_meet_at_NATO_headquarters_in_Brussels_2010.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">
         Turkish Armed Forces
        </a>
        collectively rank as the second largest standing military force in
        <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
         NATO
        </a>
        , after the
        <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">
         U.S. Armed Forces
        </a>
        . Turkey joined the alliance in
        <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Original_and_joining_members" title="Member states of NATO">
         1952
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign_160-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign-160">
          [159]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">
       Turkish Armed Forces
      </a>
      consists of the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Land_Forces" title="Turkish Land Forces">
       Land Forces
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Naval_Forces" title="Turkish Naval Forces">
       Naval Forces
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Air_Force" title="Turkish Air Force">
       Air Force
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Gendarmerie" title="Turkish Gendarmerie">
       Gendarmerie
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Coast_Guard" title="Turkish Coast Guard">
       Coast Guard
      </a>
      operate as parts of the Ministry of Internal Affairs in peacetime, although they are subordinated to the Army and Navy Commands respectively in wartime, during which they have both internal law enforcement and military functions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSK_Organisation_161-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TSK_Organisation-161">
        [160]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chief_of_the_Turkish_General_Staff" title="Chief of the Turkish General Staff">
       Chief of the General Staff
      </a>
      is appointed by the President and is responsible to the Prime Minister. The Council of Ministers is responsible to the Parliament for matters of national security and the adequate preparation of the armed forces to defend the country. However, the authority to declare war and to deploy the Turkish Armed Forces to foreign countries or to allow foreign armed forces to be stationed in Turkey rests solely with the Parliament.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSK_Organisation_161-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TSK_Organisation-161">
        [160]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey has the
      <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Military_personnel" title="Member states of NATO">
       second largest standing military force
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
       NATO
      </a>
      , after the
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">
       U.S. Armed Forces
      </a>
      , with an estimated strength of 495,000 deployable forces, according to a 2011 NATO estimate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
       <a href="#cite_note-162">
        [161]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey is one of five NATO member states which are part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_sharing" title="Nuclear sharing">
       nuclear sharing
      </a>
      policy of the alliance, together with Belgium,
      <a href="/wiki/Germany_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Germany and weapons of mass destruction">
       Germany
      </a>
      , Italy, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Netherlands and weapons of mass destruction">
       Netherlands
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        [162]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 90
      <a href="/wiki/B61_nuclear_bomb" title="B61 nuclear bomb">
       B61 nuclear bombs
      </a>
      are hosted at the
      <a href="/wiki/Incirlik_Air_Base" title="Incirlik Air Base">
       Incirlik Air Base
      </a>
      , 40 of which are allocated for use by the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Air_Force" title="Turkish Air Force">
       Turkish Air Force
      </a>
      in case of a nuclear conflict, but their use requires the approval of NATO.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
       <a href="#cite_note-164">
        [163]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Every fit male Turkish citizen otherwise not barred is required to
      <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Turkey" title="Conscription in Turkey">
       serve in the military
      </a>
      for a period ranging from three weeks to a year, dependent on education and job location.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
       <a href="#cite_note-165">
        [164]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey does not recognise conscientious objection and does not offer a civilian alternative to military service.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
       <a href="#cite_note-166">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
       Geography
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Turkey" title="Geography of Turkey">
       Geography of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_topo.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="752" data-file-width="1400" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/250px-Turkey_topo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/375px-Turkey_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/500px-Turkey_topo.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_topo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Topographic map of Turkey
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey is a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transcontinental_country" title="Transcontinental country">
       transcontinental
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immerfall2009_167-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Immerfall2009-167">
        [166]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Eurasian country. Asian Turkey, which includes 97 percent of the country, is separated from European Turkey by the
      <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
       Bosphorus
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">
       Sea of Marmara
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">
       Dardanelles
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">
       European Turkey
      </a>
      comprises 3 percent of the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkeygeoth_168-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-turkeygeoth-168">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The territory of Turkey is more than 1,600 kilometres (990 miles) long and 800 kilometres (500 miles) wide, with a roughly rectangular shape.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USLC_TRGeo_169-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USLC_TRGeo-169">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It lies between latitudes
      <a href="/wiki/35th_parallel_north" title="35th parallel north">
       35°
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/43rd_parallel_north" title="43rd parallel north">
       43° N
      </a>
      , and longitudes
      <a href="/wiki/25th_meridian_east" title="25th meridian east">
       25°
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/45th_meridian_east" title="45th meridian east">
       45° E
      </a>
      . Turkey's land area, including lakes, occupies 783,562 square kilometres (302,535 square miles),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
       <a href="#cite_note-170">
        [169]
       </a>
      </sup>
      of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 square miles) are in Southwest Asia and 23,764 square kilometres (9,175 square miles) in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USLC_TRGeo_169-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-USLC_TRGeo-169">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey is the world's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">
       37th-largest
      </a>
      country in terms of area. The country is encircled by seas on three sides: the
      <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">
       Aegean Sea
      </a>
      to the west, the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
       Black Sea
      </a>
      to the north and the Mediterranean to the south. Turkey also contains the
      <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">
       Sea of Marmara
      </a>
      in the northwest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism_171-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism-171">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="804" data-file-width="1200" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg/220px-Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg/330px-Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg/440px-Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Akhtamar_Island_on_Lake_Van_with_the_Armenian_Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A photograph of
        <a href="/wiki/Lake_Van" title="Lake Van">
         Lake Van
        </a>
        and the
        <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Cross,_Aghtamar" title="Cathedral of the Holy Cross, Aghtamar">
         Armenian Church
        </a>
        of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Akhtamar" title="Akhtamar">
         Akhtamar
        </a>
        . Van is the largest lake in the country and is located in eastern Anatolia.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lvan_172-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-lvan-172">
          [171]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The European section of Turkey,
      <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">
       East Thrace
      </a>
      (the easternmost region of the
      <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
       Balkan
      </a>
      peninsula), forms the borders of Turkey with Greece and Bulgaria. The Asian part of the country is comprised mostly by the peninsula of
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
       Anatolia
      </a>
      , which consists of a high central plateau with narrow coastal plains, between the
      <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ro%C4%9Flu_Mountains" title="Köroğlu Mountains">
       Köroğlu
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">
       Pontic
      </a>
      mountain ranges to the north and the
      <a href="/wiki/Taurus_Mountains" title="Taurus Mountains">
       Taurus Mountains
      </a>
      to the south.
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">
       Eastern Turkey
      </a>
      , located within the western plateau of the
      <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Highlands" title="Armenian Highlands">
       Armenian Highlands
      </a>
      , has a more mountainous landscape and is home to the sources of rivers such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Euphrates" title="Euphrates">
       Euphrates
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tigris" title="Tigris">
       Tigris
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aras_River" title="Aras River">
       Aras
      </a>
      , and contains
      <a href="/wiki/Mount_Ararat" title="Mount Ararat">
       Mount Ararat
      </a>
      , Turkey's highest point at 5,137 metres (16,854 feet),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mararat_173-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mararat-173">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Lake_Van" title="Lake Van">
       Lake Van
      </a>
      , the largest lake in the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lvan_172-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-lvan-172">
        [171]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Southeastern Anatolia Region">
       Southeastern Turkey
      </a>
      is located within the northern plains of
      <a href="/wiki/Upper_Mesopotamia" title="Upper Mesopotamia">
       Upper Mesopotamia
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey is divided into
      <a href="/wiki/Geographical_regions_of_Turkey" title="Geographical regions of Turkey">
       seven geographical regions
      </a>
      :
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marmara_Region,_Turkey" title="Marmara Region, Turkey">
       Marmara
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aegean_Region,_Turkey" title="Aegean Region, Turkey">
       Aegean
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region,_Turkey" title="Black Sea Region, Turkey">
       Black Sea
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" title="Central Anatolia Region, Turkey">
       Central Anatolia
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" title="East Anatolia Region, Turkey">
       Eastern Anatolia
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Eastern_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" title="South Eastern Anatolia Region, Turkey">
       Southeastern Anatolia
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea_Region,_Turkey" title="Mediterranean Sea Region, Turkey">
       Mediterranean
      </a>
      . The uneven north Anatolian terrain running along the Black Sea resembles a long, narrow belt. This region comprises approximately one-sixth of Turkey's total land area. As a general trend, the inland Anatolian plateau becomes increasingly rugged as it progresses eastward.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism_171-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism-171">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey's varied landscapes are the product of complex earth movements that have shaped the region over thousands of years and still manifest themselves in fairly frequent earthquakes and occasional
      <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">
       volcanic
      </a>
      eruptions. The
      <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
       Bosphorus
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">
       Dardanelles
      </a>
      owe their existence to the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geologic_fault" title="Geologic fault">
       fault lines
      </a>
      running through Turkey that led to the creation of the Black Sea. The
      <a href="/wiki/North_Anatolian_Fault" title="North Anatolian Fault">
       North Anatolian Fault Line
      </a>
      runs across the north of the country from west to east, along which major earthquakes took place in history. The latest of those big earthquakes was the
      <a href="/wiki/1999_%C4%B0zmit_earthquake" title="1999 İzmit earthquake">
       1999 İzmit earthquake
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">
       Biodiversity
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flora_and_vegetation_of_Turkey" title="Flora and vegetation of Turkey">
       Flora and vegetation of Turkey
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Turkey" title="Wildlife of Turkey">
       Wildlife of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Turkey" title="Environmental issues in Turkey">
       Environmental issues in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3456" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/220px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/330px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/440px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%BCmela_Monastery" title="Sümela Monastery">
         Sümela Monastery
        </a>
        on the
        <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">
         Pontic Mountains
        </a>
        . These mountains form an
        <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">
         ecoregion
        </a>
        with
        <a href="/wiki/Northern_Anatolian_conifer_and_deciduous_forests" title="Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests">
         diverse temperate rainforest types
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">
         flora
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">
         fauna
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey's extraordinary
      <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">
       ecosystem
      </a>
      and habitat diversity has produced considerable species diversity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        [173]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
       Anatolia
      </a>
      is the homeland of many plants that have been cultivated for food since the advent of
      <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">
       agriculture
      </a>
      , and the wild ancestors of many plants that now provide staples for humankind still grow in Turkey. The diversity of Turkey's
      <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">
       fauna
      </a>
      is even greater than that of its
      <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">
       flora
      </a>
      . The number of animal species in the whole of
      <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
       Europe
      </a>
      is around 60,000, while in Turkey there are over 80,000 (over 100,000 counting the subspecies).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allaboutturkey_175-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-allaboutturkey-175">
        [174]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Anatolian_conifer_and_deciduous_forests" title="Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests">
       Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests
      </a>
      is an
      <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">
       ecoregion
      </a>
      which covers most of the
      <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">
       Pontic Mountains
      </a>
      in northern Turkey, while the
      <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_mixed_forests" title="Caucasus mixed forests">
       Caucasus mixed forests
      </a>
      extend across the eastern end of the range. The region is home to
      <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">
       Eurasian
      </a>
      wildlife such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_sparrowhawk" title="Eurasian sparrowhawk">
       Eurasian sparrowhawk
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Golden_eagle" title="Golden eagle">
       golden eagle
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_imperial_eagle" title="Eastern imperial eagle">
       eastern imperial eagle
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lesser_spotted_eagle" title="Lesser spotted eagle">
       lesser spotted eagle
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caucasian_black_grouse" title="Caucasian black grouse">
       Caucasian black grouse
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Red-fronted_serin" title="Red-fronted serin">
       red-fronted serin
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Wallcreeper" title="Wallcreeper">
       wallcreeper
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
       <a href="#cite_note-176">
        [175]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The narrow coastal strip between the Pontic Mountains and the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
       Black Sea
      </a>
      is home to the
      <a href="/wiki/Euxine-Colchic_deciduous_forests" title="Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests">
       Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests
      </a>
      , which contain some of the world's few
      <a href="/wiki/Temperate_rainforest" title="Temperate rainforest">
       temperate rainforests
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
       <a href="#cite_note-177">
        [176]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_pine" title="Turkish pine">
       Turkish pine
      </a>
      is mostly found in Turkey and other east Mediterranean countries. Several wild species of
      <a href="/wiki/Tulip" title="Tulip">
       tulip
      </a>
      are native to Anatolia, and the flower was first
      <a href="/wiki/Tulip#Introduction_to_Western_Europe" title="Tulip">
       introduced to Western Europe
      </a>
      with species taken from the Ottoman Empire in the 16th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blunt_7_178-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Blunt_7-178">
        [177]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
       <a href="#cite_note-179">
        [178]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There are
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Turkey" title="List of national parks of Turkey">
       40 national parks
      </a>
      , 189 nature parks, 31 nature preserve areas, 80 wildlife protection areas and 109 nature monuments in Turkey such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Peninsula_Historical_National_Park" title="Gallipoli Peninsula Historical National Park">
       Gallipoli Peninsula Historical National Park
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mount_Nemrut_National_Park" title="Mount Nemrut National Park">
       Mount Nemrut National Park
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Troya_National_Park" title="Ancient Troya National Park">
       Ancient Troya National Park
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%96l%C3%BCdeniz_Nature_Park" title="Ölüdeniz Nature Park">
       Ölüdeniz Nature Park
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polonezk%C3%B6y_Nature_Park" title="Polonezköy Nature Park">
       Polonezköy Nature Park
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforest_180-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforest-180">
        [179]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">
       Ankara
      </a>
      , the capital of Turkey, is renowned for the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora" title="Turkish Angora">
       Angora cat
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Angora_rabbit" title="Angora rabbit">
       Angora rabbit
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Angora_goat" title="Angora goat">
       Angora goat
      </a>
      . Another national cat breed of Turkey is the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Van" title="Turkish Van">
       Van cat
      </a>
      . The national dog breeds are the
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_Shepherd" title="Anatolian Shepherd">
       Anatolian Shepherd
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kangal_dog" title="Kangal dog">
       Kangal
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Aksaray_Malaklisi_dog" title="Aksaray Malaklisi dog">
       Malaklı
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Akbash_Dog" title="Akbash Dog">
       Akbaş
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gateofturkey_181-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-gateofturkey-181">
        [180]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The last confirmed death of an
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_leopard" title="Anatolian leopard">
       Anatolian leopard
      </a>
      , closely related to the
      <a href="/wiki/Persian_leopard" title="Persian leopard">
       Persian (Caucasian) leopard
      </a>
      and native to the western regions of Anatolia, took place in the Bağözü village of the
      <a href="/wiki/Beypazar%C4%B1,_Ankara" title="Beypazarı, Ankara">
       Beypazarı
      </a>
      district in
      <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Province" title="Ankara Province">
       Ankara Province
      </a>
      on 17 January 1974.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ert.C3.BCz.C3.BCn06_182-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ert.C3.BCz.C3.BCn06-182">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iucn_183-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-iucn-183">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Persian (Caucasian) leopard is still found in very small numbers in the northeastern and southeastern regions of Turkey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O.E.Can_184-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-O.E.Can-184">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
       <a href="#cite_note-185">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Caspian_tiger" title="Caspian tiger">
       Caspian tiger
      </a>
      is an extinct tiger subspecies (closely related to the
      <a href="/wiki/Siberian_tiger" title="Siberian tiger">
       Siberian tiger
      </a>
      ) which lived in the easternmost regions of Turkey until the latter half of the 20th century, with the last confirmed death in
      <a href="/wiki/Uludere" title="Uludere">
       Uludere
      </a>
      , February 1970.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O.E.Can_184-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-O.E.Can-184">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-.C3.9Cstay_186-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-.C3.9Cstay-186">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">
       Eurasian lynx
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/European_wildcat" title="European wildcat">
       European wildcat
      </a>
      are other
      <a href="/wiki/Felidae" title="Felidae">
       felid
      </a>
      species which are currently found in the forests of Turkey.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
       Climate
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Turkey" title="Climate of Turkey">
       Climate of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_koppen.svg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="792" data-file-width="1152" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Turkey_koppen.svg/220px-Turkey_koppen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Turkey_koppen.svg/330px-Turkey_koppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Turkey_koppen.svg/440px-Turkey_koppen.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_koppen.svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Köppen climate types of Turkey
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The coastal areas of Turkey bordering the
      <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">
       Aegean
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
       Mediterranean Seas
      </a>
      have a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate" title="Temperate">
       temperate
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">
       Mediterranean climate
      </a>
      , with hot, dry summers and mild to cool, wet winters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The coastal areas bordering the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
       Black Sea
      </a>
      have a temperate
      <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">
       oceanic climate
      </a>
      with warm, wet summers and cool to cold, wet
      <a href="/wiki/Winter" title="Winter">
       winters
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Turkish Black Sea coast receives the greatest amount of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">
       precipitation
      </a>
      and is the only region of Turkey that receives high precipitation throughout the year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The eastern part of that coast averages 2,200 millimetres (87 in) annually which is the highest precipitation in the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The coastal areas bordering the
      <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">
       Sea of Marmara
      </a>
      , which connects the Aegean Sea and the Black Sea, have a transitional climate between a temperate Mediterranean climate and a temperate oceanic climate with warm to hot, moderately dry
      <a href="/wiki/Summer" title="Summer">
       summers
      </a>
      and cool to cold, wet winters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Snow falls on the coastal areas of the Sea of Marmara and the Black Sea almost every winter, but usually melts in no more than a few days.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However snow is rare in the coastal areas of the Aegean Sea and very rare in the coastal areas of the Mediterranean Sea.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_(Sensoy,_S._et_al,_2008).png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="797" data-file-width="1306" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png/220px-Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png/330px-Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png/440px-Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_%28Sensoy%2C_S._et_al%2C_2008%29.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Climate_diagram_of_Turkey_(Sensoy,_S._et_al,_2008).png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Climate diagram of Turkey
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-7">
         <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
          [186]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Mountains close to the coast prevent Mediterranean influences from extending inland, giving the central Anatolian
      <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">
       plateau
      </a>
      of the interior of Turkey a
      <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">
       continental climate
      </a>
      with sharply contrasting
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seasons" title="Seasons">
       seasons
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Winters on the eastern part of the plateau are especially severe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Temperatures of −30 to −40 °C (−22 to −40 °F) can occur in eastern Anatolia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Snow may remain at least 120 days of the year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the west, winter temperatures average below 1 °C (34 °F).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Summers are hot and dry, with temperatures often above 30 °C (86 °F) in the day.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Annual
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">
       precipitation
      </a>
      averages about 400 millimetres (15 in), with actual amounts determined by elevation. The driest regions are the Konya plain and the Malatya plain, where annual rainfall is often less than 300 millimetres (12 in). May is generally the wettest month, whereas July and August are the driest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_187-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteo-187">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
       Economy
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">
       Economy of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014,_p9.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014%2C_p9.JPG/300px-%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014%2C_p9.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014%2C_p9.JPG/450px-%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014%2C_p9.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014%2C_p9.JPG/600px-%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014%2C_p9.JPG 2x" width="300"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_view_from_%C4%B0stanbul_Sapphire_observation_deck_Aug_2014,_p9.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Skyscrapers of
        <a href="/wiki/Levent" title="Levent">
         Levent
        </a>
        business district in
        <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
         Istanbul
        </a>
        , Turkey's largest city and leading economic center.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hurriyetdailynews2_188-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-hurriyetdailynews2-188">
          [187]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey has the world's
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">
       17th largest GDP by PPP
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WB-GDP-PPP_189-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WB-GDP-PPP-189">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">
       18th largest nominal GDP
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WB-GDP_190-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WB-GDP-190">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country is among the founding members of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">
       G-20
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign1_126-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign1-126">
        [125]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign2_132-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign2-132">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Union_%E2%80%93_Turkey_Customs_Union" title="European Union – Turkey Customs Union">
       EU – Turkey Customs Union
      </a>
      in 1995 led to an extensive liberalization of tariff rates, and forms one of the most important pillars of Turkey's foreign trade policy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
       <a href="#cite_note-191">
        [190]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey's exports were $143.5 billion in 2011 and reached $163 billion in 2012 (main export partners in 2012: Germany 8.6%,
      <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">
       Iraq
      </a>
      7.1%,
      <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
       Iran
      </a>
      6.5%,
      <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
       UK
      </a>
      5.7%,
      <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">
       UAE
      </a>
