      5.4%). However, larger imports which amounted to $229 billion in 2012 threatened the balance of trade (main import partners in 2012: Russia 11.3%, Germany 9%, China 9%,
      <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
       US
      </a>
      6%, Italy 5.6%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-8">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey has a sizeable
      <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Turkey" title="Automotive industry in Turkey">
       automotive industry
      </a>
      , which produced over 1.3 million motor vehicles in 2015, ranking as the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of countries by motor vehicle production">
       14th largest producer in the world
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oica_192-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-oica-192">
        [191]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkish
      <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding" title="Shipbuilding">
       shipbuilding
      </a>
      exports were worth US$1.2 billion in 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ship-moe_193-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ship-moe-193">
        [192]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The major export markets are Malta, Marshall Islands, Panama and the United Kingdom. Turkish shipyards have 15
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Floating_dry_dock" title="Floating dry dock">
       floating docks
      </a>
      of different sizes and one
      <a href="/wiki/Dry_dock" title="Dry dock">
       dry dock
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ship-moe_193-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ship-moe-193">
        [192]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tuzla, Yalova, and İzmit have developed into dynamic shipbuilding centres.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ship-oecd_194-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ship-oecd-194">
        [193]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2011, there were 70 active shipyards in Turkey, with another 56 being built.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ship-oecd_194-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ship-oecd-194">
        [193]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkish shipyards are highly regarded both for the production of chemical and
      <a href="/wiki/Oil_tanker" title="Oil tanker">
       oil tankers
      </a>
      up to 10,000
      <a href="/wiki/Deadweight_tonnage" title="Deadweight tonnage">
       dwt
      </a>
      and also for their
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mega_yacht" title="Mega yacht">
       mega yachts
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ship-oecd_194-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-ship-oecd-194">
        [193]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:144px;max-width:144px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:142px;max-width:142px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Beko_logo.svg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="83" data-file-width="144" height="81" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/New_Beko_logo.svg/140px-New_Beko_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/New_Beko_logo.svg/210px-New_Beko_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/New_Beko_logo.svg/280px-New_Beko_logo.svg.png 2x" width="140"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:142px;max-width:142px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vestel_logo.svg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="317" data-file-width="849" height="52" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vestel_logo.svg/140px-Vestel_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vestel_logo.svg/210px-Vestel_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vestel_logo.svg/280px-Vestel_logo.svg.png 2x" width="140"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <a href="/wiki/Beko" title="Beko">
          Beko
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Vestel" title="Vestel">
          Vestel
         </a>
         are among the largest producers of
         <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">
          consumer electronics
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Home_appliances" title="Home appliances">
          home appliances
         </a>
         in Europe.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkish brands like
      <a href="/wiki/Beko" title="Beko">
       Beko
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Vestel" title="Vestel">
       Vestel
      </a>
      are among the largest producers of
      <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">
       consumer electronics
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Home_appliances" title="Home appliances">
       home appliances
      </a>
      in Europe, and invest a substantial amount of funds for research and development in new technologies related to these fields.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
       <a href="#cite_note-195">
        [194]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
       <a href="#cite_note-196">
        [195]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
       <a href="#cite_note-197">
        [196]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Other key sectors of the Turkish economy are banking, construction, home appliances, electronics, textiles, oil refining, petrochemical products, food, mining, iron and steel, and
      <a href="/wiki/Machine_industry" title="Machine industry">
       machine industry
      </a>
      . In 2010, the agricultural sector accounted for 9 percent of GDP, while the industrial sector accounted for 26 percent and the services sector for 65 percent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-8">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, agriculture still accounted for a quarter of employment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
       <a href="#cite_note-198">
        [197]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2004, it was estimated that 46 percent of total disposable income was received by the top 20 percent of income earners, while the lowest 20 percent received only 6 percent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
       <a href="#cite_note-199">
        [198]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The rate of female employment in Turkey was 30 percent in 2012,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
       <a href="#cite_note-200">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the lowest among all OECD countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
       <a href="#cite_note-201">
        [200]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">
       Foreign direct investment
      </a>
      (FDI) was $8.3 billion in 2012, a figure expected to rise to $15 billion in 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
       <a href="#cite_note-202">
        [201]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2012,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fitch_Group" title="Fitch Group">
       Fitch Group
      </a>
      upgraded Turkey's
      <a href="/wiki/Credit_rating" title="Credit rating">
       credit rating
      </a>
      to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Investment_grade" title="Investment grade">
       investment grade
      </a>
      after an 18-year gap;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
       <a href="#cite_note-203">
        [202]
       </a>
      </sup>
      this was followed by a ratings upgrade by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moody%27s" title="Moody's">
       Moody's
      </a>
      in May 2013, as the service lifted Turkey's government bond ratings to the lowest investment grade Baa3.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
       <a href="#cite_note-204">
        [203]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
       <a href="#cite_note-205">
        [204]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History_2">
       History
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Turkey" title="Economic history of Turkey">
       Economic history of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="375" data-file-width="536" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg/220px-Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg/330px-Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg/440px-Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk-Nazilli-Cottonfactory.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
         Atatürk
        </a>
        (center) accompanied by
        <a href="/wiki/Cel%C3%A2l_Bayar" title="Celâl Bayar">
         Bayar
        </a>
        (to his left) and
        <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="İsmet İnönü">
         İnönü
        </a>
        (to his right) at the
        <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCmerbank" title="Sümerbank">
         Sümerbank
        </a>
        Textile Factory in
        <a href="/wiki/Nazilli" title="Nazilli">
         Nazilli
        </a>
        , 9 October 1937.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In the early decades of the Turkish Republic, the government (or banks established and owned by the government, such as
      <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_%C4%B0%C5%9F_Bankas%C4%B1" title="Türkiye İş Bankası">
       Türkiye İş Bankası
      </a>
      (1924), Sanayi ve Maadin Bankası (1925), Emlak ve Eytam Bankası (1926),
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey">
       Central Bank of Turkey
      </a>
      (1930),
      <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCmerbank" title="Sümerbank">
       Sümerbank
      </a>
      (1933),
      <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0lbank" title="İlbank">
       İller Bankası
      </a>
      (1933),
      <a href="/wiki/Etibank" title="Etibank">
       Etibank
      </a>
      (1935),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Denizbank" title="Denizbank">
       Denizbank
      </a>
      (1937),
      <a href="/wiki/Halk_Bankas%C4%B1" title="Halk Bankası">
       Halk Bankası
      </a>
      (1938), etc.) had to subsidize most of the industrial projects, due to the lack of a strong
      <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">
       private sector
      </a>
      . However, in the period between the 1920s and 1950s, a new generation of Turkish
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entrepreneur" title="Entrepreneur">
       entrepreneurs
      </a>
      such as
      <a href="/wiki/Nuri_Demira%C4%9F" title="Nuri Demirağ">
       Nuri Demirağ
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Vehbi_Ko%C3%A7" title="Vehbi Koç">
       Vehbi Koç
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hac%C4%B1_%C3%96mer_Sabanc%C4%B1" title="Hacı Ömer Sabancı">
       Hacı Ömer Sabancı
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Nejat_Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1" title="Nejat Eczacıbaşı">
       Nejat Eczacıbaşı
      </a>
      began to establish privately owned factories, some of which evolved into the largest industrial
      <a href="/wiki/Conglomerate_(company)" title="Conglomerate (company)">
       conglomerates
      </a>
      that dominate the Turkish economy today, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Ko%C3%A7_Holding" title="Koç Holding">
       Koç Holding
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sabanc%C4%B1_Holding" title="Sabancı Holding">
       Sabancı Holding
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1" title="Eczacıbaşı">
       Eczacıbaşı Holding
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      During the first six decades of the republic, between 1923 and 1983, Turkey generally adhered to a quasi-
      <a href="/wiki/Statism" title="Statism">
       statist
      </a>
      approach with strict government planning of the
      <a href="/wiki/Government_budget" title="Government budget">
       budget
      </a>
      and government-imposed limitations over
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_trade" title="Foreign trade">
       foreign trade
      </a>
      , flow of
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">
       foreign currency
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">
       foreign direct investment
      </a>
      and private sector participation in certain fields (such as
      <a href="/wiki/Broadcasting" title="Broadcasting">
       broadcasting
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telecommunications" title="Telecommunications">
       telecommunications
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_industry" title="Energy industry">
       energy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mining" title="Mining">
       mining
      </a>
      , etc.). However, in 1983, Prime Minister
      <a href="/wiki/Turgut_%C3%96zal" title="Turgut Özal">
       Turgut Özal
      </a>
      initiated a series of reforms designed to shift the economy from a statist, insulated system to a more private-sector,
      <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">
       market
      </a>
      -based model.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80sLiberalization_100-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-80sLiberalization-100">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The reforms, combined with unprecedented amounts of funding from foreign loans, spurred rapid economic growth; but this growth was punctuated by sharp
      <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">
       recessions
      </a>
      and financial crises in 1994, 1999 (following the
      <a href="/wiki/1999_%C4%B0zmit_earthquake" title="1999 İzmit earthquake">
       earthquake
      </a>
      of that year),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
       <a href="#cite_note-206">
        [205]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 2001;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
       <a href="#cite_note-207">
        [206]
       </a>
      </sup>
      resulting in an average of 4 percent GDP growth per annum between 1981 and 2003.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
       <a href="#cite_note-208">
        [207]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Lack of additional fiscal reforms, combined with large and growing
      <a href="/wiki/Public_sector" title="Public sector">
       public sector
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_budget_deficit" title="Government budget deficit">
       deficits
      </a>
      and widespread corruption, resulted in high inflation, a weak
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_banks_in_Turkey" title="List of banks in Turkey">
       banking
      </a>
      sector and increased
      <a href="/wiki/Macroeconomics" title="Macroeconomics">
       macroeconomic
      </a>
      volatility.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
       <a href="#cite_note-209">
        [208]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Stock_Market_Crash_of_2001" title="Turkish Stock Market Crash of 2001">
       economic crisis of 2001
      </a>
      and the reforms initiated by the finance minister of the time,
      <a href="/wiki/Kemal_Dervi%C5%9F" title="Kemal Derviş">
       Kemal Derviş
      </a>
      , inflation has dropped to single-digit figures for the first time in decades (8% in 2005), investor confidence and foreign investment have soared, and unemployment has fallen (10% in 2005).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WorldBank_TRStat_210-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WorldBank_TRStat-210">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey has gradually opened up its markets through economic reforms by reducing government controls on foreign trade and investment and the
      <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">
       privatization
      </a>
      of publicly owned industries, and the liberalization of many sectors to private and foreign participation has continued amid political debate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_Eco_211-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TR_Eco-211">
        [210]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The public
      <a href="/wiki/Debt-to-GDP_ratio" title="Debt-to-GDP ratio">
       debt-to-GDP ratio
      </a>
      peaked at 75.9 percent during the recession of 2001, falling to an estimated 26.9 percent by 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pdebt_212-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pdebt-212">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The real GDP growth rate from 2002 to 2007 averaged 6.8 percent annually,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
       <a href="#cite_note-213">
        [212]
       </a>
      </sup>
      which made Turkey one of the fastest growing economies in the world during that period. However, growth slowed to 1 percent in 2008, and in 2009 the Turkish economy was affected by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_financial_crisis" title="Late-2000s financial crisis">
       global financial crisis
      </a>
      , with a recession of 5 percent. The economy was estimated to have returned to 8 percent growth in 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-8">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to
      <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
       Eurostat
      </a>
      data, Turkish GDP per capita adjusted by
      <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power" title="Purchasing power">
       purchasing power
      </a>
      standard stood at 52 percent of the EU average in 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
       <a href="#cite_note-214">
        [213]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the early years of the 21st century, the chronically high inflation was brought under control; this led to the launch of a new currency, the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_lira#8th_Emission_group" title="Turkish lira">
       Turkish new lira
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       Yeni Türk Lirası
      </i>
      ) in 2005, to cement the acquisition of the economic reforms and erase the vestiges of an unstable economy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
       <a href="#cite_note-215">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2009, after only four years in circulation, the
      <i>
       Turkish new lira
      </i>
      was renamed back to the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_lira" title="Turkish lira">
       Turkish lira
      </a>
      with the introduction of
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_lira#9th_Emission_group" title="Turkish lira">
       new banknotes
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Lira#Coins" title="Turkish Lira">
       coins
      </a>
      (and the withdrawal of the
      <i>
       Turkish new lira
      </i>
      banknotes and coins that were introduced in 2005), but the
      <a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">
       ISO 4217
      </a>
      code of the
      <i>
       Turkish new lira
      </i>
      (TRY) remains in use for the current
      <i>
       Turkish lira
      </i>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">
       foreign exchange market
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
       Tourism
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Turkey" title="Tourism in Turkey">
       Tourism in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alanyafromcastle.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2278" data-file-width="3264" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Alanyafromcastle.JPG/220px-Alanyafromcastle.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Alanyafromcastle.JPG/330px-Alanyafromcastle.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Alanyafromcastle.JPG/440px-Alanyafromcastle.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alanyafromcastle.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Most of the beach resorts in Turkey are located in the
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Riviera" title="Turkish Riviera">
         Turkish Riviera
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Turkey" title="Tourism in Turkey">
       Tourism in Turkey
      </a>
      has experienced rapid growth in the last twenty years, and constitutes an important part of the economy. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Ministry_of_Culture_and_Tourism" title="Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism">
       Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism
      </a>
      currently promotes Turkish tourism under the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkey_Home" title="Turkey Home">
       Turkey Home
      </a>
      name. In 2013, 37.8 million foreign visitors arrived in Turkey, which ranked as the
      <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings#International_tourist_arrivals_by_country_of_destination_2011" title="World Tourism rankings">
       6th most popular tourism destination in the world
      </a>
      ; they contributed $27.9 billion to Turkey's revenues.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNWTO_216-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UNWTO-216">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2012, 15 percent of the tourists were from Germany, 11 percent from Russia, 8 percent from the United Kingdom, 5 percent from
      <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">
       Bulgaria
      </a>
      , 4 percent each from
      <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">
       Georgia
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">
       Netherlands
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
       Iran
      </a>
      , 3 percent from France, 2 percent each from the United States and
      <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">
       Syria
      </a>
      , and 40 percent from other countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TurkStat1_217-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TurkStat1-217">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey has
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">
       13 UNESCO World Heritage Sites
      </a>
      , such as the "
      <a href="/wiki/Historic_Areas_of_Istanbul" title="Historic Areas of Istanbul">
       Historic Areas of Istanbul
      </a>
      ", the "Rock Sites of
      <a href="/wiki/Cappadocia" title="Cappadocia">
       Cappadocia
      </a>
      ", the "Neolithic Site of
      <a href="/wiki/%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Çatalhöyük">
       Çatalhöyük
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Hattusa" title="Hattusa">
       Hattusa
      </a>
      : the
      <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">
       Hittite
      </a>
      Capital", the "Archaeological Site of
      <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">
       Troy
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Pergamon" title="Pergamon">
       Pergamon
      </a>
      and its Multi-Layered Cultural Landscape", "
      <a href="/wiki/Hierapolis" title="Hierapolis">
       Hierapolis
      </a>
      –
      <a href="/wiki/Pamukkale" title="Pamukkale">
       Pamukkale
      </a>
      ", and "
      <a href="/wiki/Mount_Nemrut" title="Mount Nemrut">
       Mount Nemrut
      </a>
      ";
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
       <a href="#cite_note-218">
        [217]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey_(Tentative_list)" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey (Tentative list)">
       51 World Heritage Sites in tentative list
      </a>
      , such as the archaeological sites or historic urban centers of
      <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">
       Göbekli Tepe
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gordion" title="Gordion">
       Gordion
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">
       Ephesus
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Aphrodisias" title="Aphrodisias">
       Aphrodisias
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Perga" title="Perga">
       Perga
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lycia" title="Lycia">
       Lycia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sagalassos" title="Sagalassos">
       Sagalassos
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Aizanoi" title="Aizanoi">
       Aizanoi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Zeugma" title="Zeugma">
       Zeugma
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ani" title="Ani">
       Ani
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Harran" title="Harran">
       Harran
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mardin" title="Mardin">
       Mardin
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
       Konya
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Alanya" title="Alanya">
       Alanya
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whc.unesco.org1_219-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-whc.unesco.org1-219">
        [218]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey hosts two of the
      <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">
       Seven Wonders of the Ancient World
      </a>
      : the
      <a href="/wiki/Mausoleum_at_Halicarnassus" title="Mausoleum at Halicarnassus">
       Mausoleum
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Halicarnassus" title="Halicarnassus">
       Halicarnassus
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Artemis" title="Temple of Artemis">
       Temple of Artemis
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">
       Ephesus
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-historyworld_220-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-historyworld-220">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:99%; max-width:758px;">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="">
       <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Goreme_banner2.jpg" title="Cappadocia is a region created by the erosion of soft volcanic stone by the wind and rain for centuries. The area is a popular tourist destination, having many sites with unique geological, historic, and cultural features.">
         <img alt="" data-file-height="1637" data-file-width="4911" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Goreme_banner2.jpg/750px-Goreme_banner2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Goreme_banner2.jpg/1125px-Goreme_banner2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Goreme_banner2.jpg/1500px-Goreme_banner2.jpg 2x" width="750"/>
        </a>
       </div>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Goreme_banner2.jpg" title="File:Goreme banner2.jpg">
         </a>
        </div>
        <center>
         <a href="/wiki/Cappadocia" title="Cappadocia">
          Cappadocia
         </a>
         is a region created by the erosion of soft volcanic stone by the wind and rain for centuries.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Capadocia_221-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Capadocia-221">
           [220]
          </a>
         </sup>
         The area is a popular tourist destination, having many sites with unique geological, historic, and cultural features.
        </center>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
       Infrastructure
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Turkey" title="Transport in Turkey">
       Transport in Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communications_in_Turkey" title="Communications in Turkey">
       Communications in Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Turkey" title="Energy in Turkey">
       Energy in Turkey
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Turkey" title="Water supply and sanitation in Turkey">
       Water supply and sanitation in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3022" data-file-width="4029" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg/220px-Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg/330px-Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg/440px-Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_Airlines_1350321.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">
         Turkish Airlines
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">
         flag carrier
        </a>
        of Turkey, has been selected by
        <a href="/wiki/Skytrax" title="Skytrax">
         Skytrax
        </a>
        as
        <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
         Europe
        </a>
        's best airline for five years in a row (2011–2015).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TurkishAirlinesSkytrax_222-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-TurkishAirlinesSkytrax-222">
          [221]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-five_223-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-five-223">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
        With destinations in 126 countries worldwide, Turkish Airlines is the
        <a href="/wiki/World%27s_largest_airlines#By_number_of_countries_served" title="World's largest airlines">
         largest carrier in the world by number of countries served
        </a>
        as of 2016
        <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
         <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">
          [update]
         </a>
        </sup>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turkish_Airlines_224-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Turkish_Airlines-224">
          [223]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg/220px-Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg/330px-Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg/440px-Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_-_Aerial_view.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus_Bridge" title="Bosphorus Bridge">
         Bosphorus Bridge
        </a>
        is the oldest of three
        <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">
         suspension bridges
        </a>
        connecting the
        <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
         European
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">
         Asian
        </a>
        sides of the
        <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
         Bosphorus
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Strait" title="Strait">
         strait
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
         Istanbul
        </a>
        . It was inaugurated on the 50th anniversary of the Turkish Republic in 1973, when it had the 4th-
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_longest_suspension_bridge_spans" title="List of longest suspension bridge spans">
         longest suspension bridge span
        </a>
        in the world, and the longest outside the United States (the longest in Europe and Asia).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
         <a href="#cite_note-225">
          [224]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
         <a href="#cite_note-226">
          [225]
         </a>
        </sup>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Marmaray" title="Marmaray">
         Marmaray
        </a>
        railway tunnel under the Bosphorus entered service on the 90th anniversary of the Republic in 2013.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 2013 there were 98
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Turkey" title="List of airports in Turkey">
       airports in Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
       <a href="#cite_note-227">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
      including 22
      <a href="/wiki/International_airport" title="International airport">
       international airports
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
       <a href="#cite_note-228">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Atat%C3%BCrk_Airport" title="Istanbul Atatürk Airport">
       Istanbul Atatürk Airport
      </a>
      is the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">
       11th busiest airport in the world
      </a>
      , serving 31,833,324 passengers between January and July 2014, according to
      <a href="/wiki/Airports_Council_International" title="Airports Council International">
       Airports Council International
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
       <a href="#cite_note-229">
        [228]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_New_Airport" title="İstanbul New Airport">
       new (third) international airport of Istanbul
      </a>
      is planned to be the largest airport in the world, with a capacity to serve 150 million passengers per annum.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhmi_230-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dhmi-230">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
       <a href="#cite_note-231">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        [231]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">
       Turkish Airlines
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">
       flag carrier
      </a>
      of Turkey since 1933, was selected by
      <a href="/wiki/Skytrax" title="Skytrax">
       Skytrax
      </a>
      as
      <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
       Europe
      </a>
      's best airline for five consecutive years in 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014 and 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TurkishAirlinesSkytrax_222-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TurkishAirlinesSkytrax-222">
        [221]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-five_223-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-five-223">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
       <a href="#cite_note-233">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines_destinations" title="Turkish Airlines destinations">
       435 destinations (51 domestic and 384 international) in 126 countries
      </a>
      worldwide, Turkish Airlines is the
      <a href="/wiki/World%27s_largest_airlines#By_number_of_countries_served" title="World's largest airlines">
       largest carrier in the world by number of countries served
      </a>
      as of 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turkish_Airlines_224-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Turkish_Airlines-224">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      As of 2014
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the country has a roadway network of 65,623 kilometres (40,776 miles).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
       <a href="#cite_note-234">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The total length of the rail network was 10,991 km in 2008, including 2,133 kilometres (1,325 miles) of electrified and 457 kilometres (284 miles) of high-speed track.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAFactbookTurkey_235-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIAFactbookTurkey-235">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr_236-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr-236">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">
       Turkish State Railways
      </a>
      started building
      <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Turkey" title="High-speed rail in Turkey">
       high-speed rail
      </a>
      lines in 2003. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ankara-Konya_high-speed_railway" title="Ankara-Konya high-speed railway">
       Ankara-Konya line
      </a>
      became operational in 2011, while the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ankara-Istanbul_high-speed_railway" title="Ankara-Istanbul high-speed railway">
       Ankara-Istanbul line
      </a>
      entered service in 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr_236-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr-236">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Opened in 2013, the
      <a href="/wiki/Marmaray" title="Marmaray">
       Marmaray tunnel
      </a>
      under the
      <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
       Bosphorus
      </a>
      connects the railway and
      <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Metro" title="Istanbul Metro">
       metro
      </a>
      lines of Istanbul's European and Asian sides; while the nearby
      <a href="/wiki/Eurasia_Tunnel" title="Eurasia Tunnel">
       Eurasia Tunnel
      </a>
      will provide an undersea road connection for motor vehicles. The
      <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus_Bridge" title="Bosphorus Bridge">
       Bosphorus Bridge
      </a>
      (1973),
      <a href="/wiki/Fatih_Sultan_Mehmet_Bridge" title="Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge">
       Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge
      </a>
      (1988) and
      <a href="/wiki/Yavuz_Sultan_Selim_Bridge" title="Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge">
       Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge
      </a>
      (2016) are the three suspension bridges connecting the European and Asian shores of the Bosphorus strait. The
      <a href="/wiki/Osman_Gazi_Bridge" title="Osman Gazi Bridge">
       Osman Gazi Bridge
      </a>
      (2016) connects the northern and southern shores of the
      <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_%C4%B0zmit" title="Gulf of İzmit">
       Gulf of İzmit
      </a>
      . The planned
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%87anakkale_Suspension_Bridge" title="Çanakkale Suspension Bridge">
       Çanakkale Bridge
      </a>
      will connect the European and Asian shores of the
      <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">
       Dardanelles
      </a>
      strait.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2008, 7,555 kilometres (4,694 mi) of
      <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">
       natural gas
      </a>
      pipelines and 3,636 kilometres (2,259 mi) of
      <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">
       petroleum
      </a>
      pipelines spanned the country's territory.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAFactbookTurkey_235-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIAFactbookTurkey-235">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan_pipeline" title="Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline">
       Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline
      </a>
      , the second longest
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_pipeline" title="Oil pipeline">
       oil pipeline
      </a>
      in the world, was inaugurated on 10 May 2005.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emreozgur.com_237-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-emreozgur.com-237">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Blue_Stream" title="Blue Stream">
       Blue Stream
      </a>
      , a major trans-
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
       Black Sea
      </a>
      gas pipeline, delivers natural gas from Russia to Turkey. New undersea pipeline, with an annual capacity around 63 billion cubic metres (bcm), will allow Turkey to resell Russian gas to Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
       <a href="#cite_note-238">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2013, the energy consumption was 240 billion
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hours" title="Kilowatt hours">
       kilowatt hours
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dwnuke_239-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dwnuke-239">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As Turkey imported 72 percent of its energy in 2013, the government decided to invest in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Turkey" title="Nuclear power in Turkey">
       nuclear power
      </a>
      to reduce imports.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dwnuke_239-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-dwnuke-239">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Three nuclear power stations are to be built by 2023.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dwnuke_239-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-dwnuke-239">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey has the fifth highest direct utilization and capacity of
      <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power_in_Turkey" title="Geothermal power in Turkey">
       geothermal power
      </a>
      in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-look_240-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-look-240">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey is a partner country of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EU" title="EU">
       EU
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/INOGATE" title="INOGATE">
       INOGATE
      </a>
      energy programme.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INOGATE_website_241-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-INOGATE_website-241">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2723" data-file-width="2255" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg/170px-TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg/255px-TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg/340px-TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TCDD_HT80000_Siemens_Velaro.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Turkey" title="High-speed rail in Turkey">
         High-speed rail
        </a>
        services of the
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">
         Turkish State Railways
        </a>
        are currently offered with
        <a href="/wiki/TCDD_HT80000" title="TCDD HT80000">
         TCDD HT80000
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/TCDD_HT65000" title="TCDD HT65000">
         TCDD HT65000
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Electric_multiple_unit" title="Electric multiple unit">
         EMU train sets
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey's first
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_energy_in_Turkey" title="Nuclear energy in Turkey">
       nuclear power plants
      </a>
      are planned to be built in
      <a href="/wiki/Mersin_Province" title="Mersin Province">
       Mersin
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/Akkuyu_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant">
       Akkuyu
      </a>
      district on the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
       Mediterranean
      </a>
      coast; in
      <a href="/wiki/Sinop_Province" title="Sinop Province">
       Sinop
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/Sinop_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Sinop Nuclear Power Plant">
       İnceburun
      </a>
      district on the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
       Black Sea
      </a>
      coast; and in
      <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1rklareli_Province" title="Kırklareli Province">
       Kırklareli
      </a>
      's İğneada district on the Black Sea coast.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turknuc_242-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-turknuc-242">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey has the fifth highest direct utilization and capacity of
      <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power_in_Turkey" title="Geothermal power in Turkey">
       geothermal power
      </a>
      in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-look_240-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-look-240">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey is a partner country of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EU" title="EU">
       EU
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/INOGATE" title="INOGATE">
       INOGATE
      </a>
      energy programme, which has four key topics: enhancing
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_security" title="Energy security">
       energy security
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Convergence_(economics)" title="Convergence (economics)">
       convergence
      </a>
      of member state
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_market" title="Energy market">
       energy markets
      </a>
      on the basis of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_energy_market" title="Internal energy market">
       EU internal energy market
      </a>
      principles, supporting
      <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_energy" title="Sustainable energy">
       sustainable energy
      </a>
      development, and attracting
      <a href="/wiki/Investment" title="Investment">
       investment
      </a>
      for energy projects of common and regional interest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INOGATE_website_241-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-INOGATE_website-241">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Internet_in_Turkey" title="Internet in Turkey">
       Turkey's internet
      </a>
      , which has 35 million
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
       <a href="#cite_note-243">
        [242]
       </a>
      </sup>
      active users, holds a 'Partly Free' ranking in
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
       Freedom House
      </a>
      's index.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_116-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-116">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Water supply and sanitation in Turkey is characterized by achievements and challenges. Over the past decades access to drinking water has become almost universal and access to adequate sanitation has also increased substantially. Autonomous utilities have been created in the 16
      <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_municipalities_in_Turkey" title="Metropolitan municipalities in Turkey">
       metropolitan cities
      </a>
      of Turkey and cost recovery has been increased, thus providing the basis for the sustainability of service provision. Intermittent supply, which was common in many cities, has become less frequent. In 2004, 61% of the wastewater collected through sewers was being treated.
     </p>
     <p>
      Remaining challenges include the need to further increase wastewater treatment, to reduce the high level of
      <a href="/wiki/Non-revenue_water" title="Non-revenue water">
       non-revenue water
      </a>
      hovering around 50% and to expand access to adequate sanitation in rural areas. The investment required to comply with EU standards in the sector, especially in wastewater treatment, is estimated to be in the order of Euro 2 billion per year, more than double the current level of investment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-did-cevreorman17_244-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-did-cevreorman17-244">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
       Science and technology
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Turkey" title="Science and technology in Turkey">
       Science and technology in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:122px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tai_logo.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="174" data-file-width="299" height="70" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Tai_logo.png/120px-Tai_logo.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Tai_logo.png/180px-Tai_logo.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Tai_logo.png/240px-Tai_logo.png 2x" width="120"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tai_logo.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Aerospace_Industries" title="Turkish Aerospace Industries">
         TAI
        </a>
        ranks among the top 100 global players in the aerospace and defence sectors.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tai.com.tr_245-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-tai.com.tr-245">
          [244]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Scientific_and_Technological_Research_Council_of_Turkey" title="Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey">
       TÜBİTAK
      </a>
      is the leading agency for developing
      <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Turkey" title="Science and technology in Turkey">
       science, technology and innovation policies in Turkey
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
       <a href="#cite_note-246">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Turkish Academy of Sciences">
       TÜBA
      </a>
      is an autonomous scholarly society acting to promote scientific activities in Turkey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
       <a href="#cite_note-247">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TAEK" title="TAEK">
       TAEK
      </a>
      is the official
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_technology" title="Nuclear technology">
       nuclear energy
      </a>
      institution of Turkey. Its objectives include academic research in nuclear energy, and the development and implementation of peaceful nuclear tools.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
       <a href="#cite_note-248">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkish government companies for
      <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">
       research and development
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Military_technology" title="Military technology">
       military technologies
      </a>
      include
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Aerospace_Industries" title="Turkish Aerospace Industries">
       Turkish Aerospace Industries
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aselsan" title="Aselsan">
       Aselsan
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Havelsan" title="Havelsan">
       Havelsan
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roketsan" title="Roketsan">
       Roketsan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mechanical_and_Chemical_Industry_Corporation" title="Mechanical and Chemical Industry Corporation">
       MKE
      </a>
      , among others.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Satellite_Assembly,_Integration_and_Test_Center" title="Turkish Satellite Assembly, Integration and Test Center">
       Turkish Satellite Assembly, Integration and Test Center
      </a>
      (UMET) is a spacecraft production and testing facility owned by the Ministry of National Defence and operated by the Turkish Aerospace Industries (TAI). The
      <a href="/wiki/Space_Launch_System_(Turkey)" title="Space Launch System (Turkey)">
       Turkish Space Launch System
      </a>
      (UFS) is a project to develop the satellite launch capability of Turkey. It consists of the construction of a
      <a href="/wiki/Spaceport" title="Spaceport">
       spaceport
      </a>
      , the development of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satellite_launch_vehicle" title="Satellite launch vehicle">
       satellite launch vehicles
      </a>
      as well as the establishment of remote earth stations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ssm1_249-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ssm1-249">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dn1_250-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dn1-250">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dn2_251-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dn2-251">
        [250]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2015,
      <a href="/wiki/Aziz_Sancar" title="Aziz Sancar">
       Aziz Sancar
      </a>
      , a Turkish professor at the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina" title="University of North Carolina">
       University of North Carolina
      </a>
      , won the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Chemistry_Prize" title="Nobel Chemistry Prize">
       Nobel Chemistry Prize
      </a>
      along with
      <a href="/wiki/Tomas_Lindahl" title="Tomas Lindahl">
       Tomas Lindahl
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paul_Modrich" title="Paul Modrich">
       Paul Modrich
      </a>
      , for their work on how cells repair damaged DNA.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
       <a href="#cite_note-252">
        [251]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other notable Turkish scientists include physician
      <a href="/wiki/Hulusi_Beh%C3%A7et" title="Hulusi Behçet">
       Hulusi Behçet
      </a>
      who discovered
      <a href="/wiki/Beh%C3%A7et%27s_disease" title="Behçet's disease">
       Behçet's disease
      </a>
      , and mathematician
      <a href="/wiki/Cahit_Arf" title="Cahit Arf">
       Cahit Arf
      </a>
      who defined the
      <a href="/wiki/Arf_invariant" title="Arf invariant">
       Arf invariant
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
       Demographics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Turkey" title="Demographics of Turkey">
       Demographics of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
       Turkish people
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Minorities_in_Turkey" title="Minorities in Turkey">
       Minorities in Turkey
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">
       Turkification
      </a>
     </div>
     <table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0 0 1em 1em;">
      <tr>
       <th class="navbox-title" colspan="3" style="padding:0.25em;font-size:110%">
        Historical populations
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr style="font-size:95%">
       <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;width:3em">
        Year
       </th>
       <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px 2px;text-align:right">
        <abbr title="Population">
         Pop.
        </abbr>
       </th>
       <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;text-align:right">
        <abbr title="Per annum growth rate">
         ±% p.a.
        </abbr>
       </th>
      </tr>

       <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">

        —
       </td>
      </tr>

       </td>

        +1.61%
       </td>

        +2.83%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">

       </th>

        +2.53%
       </td>

       </th>

       <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
        +2.32%
       </td>
      </tr>

       <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
        1990
       </th>
       <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">

       </td>
       <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
        +2.18%
       </td>
      </tr>

       <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">
        2000
       </th>

        +1.54%
       </td>

      <tr>

       </th>

        73,003,000
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">
        +1.29%
       </td>
      </tr>

       <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">

       </th>
       <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
        75,627,000
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">
        +1.78%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">
        Source: Turkstat
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop27-11_253-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-pop27-11-253">
          [252]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kurdistan_of_Turkey_(CIA).png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="977" data-file-width="2000" height="93" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/190px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/285px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/380px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png 2x" width="190"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kurdistan_of_Turkey_(CIA).png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Areas in Turkey with a Kurdish-majority population.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
         <a href="#cite_note-254">
          [253]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      According to the
      <i>
       Address-Based Population Recording System
      </i>
      of Turkey, the country's population was 74.7 million people in 2011,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011stat_255-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-2011stat-255">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
      nearly three-quarters of whom lived in
      <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">
       towns and cities
      </a>
      . According to the 2011 estimate, the population is increasing by 1.35 percent each year. Turkey has an average population density of 97 people per km². People within the 15–64
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Age_group" title="Age group">
       age group
      </a>
      constitute 67.4 percent of the total population; the 0–14 age group corresponds to 25.3 percent; while senior citizens aged 65 years or older make up 7.3 percent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1927, when the first official census was recorded in the Republic of Turkey, the population was 13.6 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
       <a href="#cite_note-257">
        [256]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The largest city in Turkey, Istanbul, is also the largest city in Europe in population, and the third-largest city in Europe in terms of size.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
       <a href="#cite_note-258">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
       <a href="#cite_note-259">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Article 66 of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">
       Turkish Constitution
      </a>
      defines a "Turk" as "anyone who is bound to the Turkish state through the bond of citizenship"; therefore, the legal use of the term "Turkish" as a
      <a href="/wiki/Citizenship" title="Citizenship">
       citizen
      </a>
      of Turkey is different from the
      <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">
       ethnic
      </a>
      definition.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yenisafak1_260-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-yenisafak1-260">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the majority of the Turkish population are of
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
       Turkish ethnicity
      </a>
      . They are estimated at 70–75 percent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-8">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Reliable data on the ethnic mix of the population is not available, because Turkish census figures do not include statistics on ethnicity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turkey_Ethnic_groups_261-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Turkey_Ethnic_groups-261">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The three "
      <a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">
       Non-Muslim
      </a>
      " minority groups claimed to be officially recognized in the
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">
       Treaty of Lausanne
      </a>
      are
      <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Turkey" title="Armenians in Turkey">
       Armenians
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Turkey" title="Greeks in Turkey">
       Greeks
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jews_in_Turkey" title="Jews in Turkey">
       Jews
      </a>
      . Officially unrecognized (mostly Muslim) ethnic groups include
      <a href="/wiki/Albanians" title="Albanians">
       Albanians
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">
       Arabs
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assyrians_in_Turkey" title="Assyrians in Turkey">
       Assyrians
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Azeris_in_Turkey" title="Azeris in Turkey">
       Azeris
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks" title="Bosniaks">
       Bosniaks
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">
       Circassians
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Georgians" title="Georgians">
       Georgians
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Laz_people" title="Laz people">
       Lazs
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">
       Persians
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pomaks" title="Pomaks">
       Pomaks (Bulgarians)
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Yazidis" title="Yazidis">
       Yazidis
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
       Roma
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minorityrights.org_262-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-minorityrights.org-262">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-joshua_263-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-joshua-263">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">
       Kurds
      </a>
      , a distinct ethnic group, are the largest non-Turkic ethnicity, around 18–25 percent of the population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-8">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mackey_264-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mackey-264">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Kurds are concentrated in the east and southeast of the country, in what is also known as
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Kurdistan" title="Turkish Kurdistan">
       Turkish Kurdistan
      </a>
      . Kurds make up a majority in the provinces of
      <a href="/wiki/Tunceli_Province" title="Tunceli Province">
       Tunceli
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bing%C3%B6l_Province" title="Bingöl Province">
       Bingöl
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mu%C5%9F_Province" title="Muş Province">
       Muş
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/A%C4%9Fr%C4%B1_Province" title="Ağrı Province">
       Ağrı
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/I%C4%9Fd%C4%B1r_Province" title="Iğdır Province">
       Iğdır
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El%C3%A2z%C4%B1%C4%9F_Province" title="Elâzığ Province">
       Elâzığ
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Diyarbak%C4%B1r_Province" title="Diyarbakır Province">
       Diyarbakır
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_Province" title="Batman Province">
       Batman
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C4%B1rnak_Province" title="Şırnak Province">
       Şırnak
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bitlis_Province" title="Bitlis Province">
       Bitlis
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Van_Province" title="Van Province">
       Van
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mardin_Province" title="Mardin Province">
       Mardin
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Siirt_Province" title="Siirt Province">
       Siirt
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hakkari_Province" title="Hakkari Province">
       Hakkari
      </a>
      , a near majority in
      <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Eanl%C4%B1urfa_Province" title="Şanlıurfa Province">
       Şanlıurfa province
      </a>
      (47%), and a large minority in
      <a href="/wiki/Kars_Province" title="Kars Province">
       Kars province
      </a>
      (20%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In addition, due to internal migration, Kurdish communities exist in all major cities in central and western Turkey, particularly in Istanbul, where there are an estimated 3 million Kurds, making Istanbul the city with the largest Kurdish population in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nachmani2003_266-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nachmani2003-266">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Minorities besides the Kurds are thought to make up an estimated 7–12 percent of the population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-8">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Minorities other than the three officially recognized ones do not have any minority rights. The term "minority" itself remains a sensitive issue in Turkey, while the Turkish government is frequently criticized for its treatment of minorities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minorities_267-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-minorities-267">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although minorities are not recognised, state-run
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">
       Turkish Radio and Television Corporation
      </a>
      (TRT) broadcasts television and radio programs in minority languages.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also, some minority language classes can be chosen in elementary schools.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-azinlikdil_270-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-azinlikdil-270">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      An estimated 2.5 percent of the population are
      <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">
       international migrants
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-esa.un.org_271-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-esa.un.org-271">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey hosts the largest number of
      <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">
       refugees
      </a>
      in the world, including 2.2 million
      <a href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War" title="Refugees of the Syrian Civil War">
       Syrian refugees
      </a>
      , as of September 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
       <a href="#cite_note-272">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
       <a href="#cite_note-274">
        [273]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
       Languages
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">
       Languages of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The country's official language is
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
       Turkish
      </a>
      , which is spoken by 85.54 percent of the population as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother_tongue" title="Mother tongue">
       mother tongue
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_275-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-275">
        [274]
       </a>
      </sup>
      11.97 percent of the population speaks the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kurmanji" title="Kurmanji">
       Kurmanji
      </a>
      dialect of
      <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_languages" title="Kurdish languages">
       Kurdish
      </a>
      as mother tongue.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_275-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-275">
        [274]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">
       Arabic
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Zaza_language" title="Zaza language">
       Zaza
      </a>
      are the mother tongues of 2.39 percent of the population, and several other languages are the mother tongues of smaller parts of the population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_275-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-275">
        [274]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Endangered_language" title="Endangered language">
       Endangered
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">
       languages in Turkey
      </a>
      include
      <a href="/wiki/Abaza_language" title="Abaza language">
       Abaza
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Abkhaz_language" title="Abkhaz language">
       Abkhaz
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Adyghe_language" title="Adyghe language">
       Adyge
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cappadocian_Greek" title="Cappadocian Greek">
       Cappadocian Greek
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Gagauz_language" title="Gagauz language">
       Gagauz
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%A9rtevin" title="Hértevin">
       Hértevin
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homshetsma" title="Homshetsma">
       Homshetsma
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kabard-Cherkes" title="Kabard-Cherkes">
       Kabard-Cherkes
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">
       Ladino (Judesmo)
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Laz_language" title="Laz language">
       Laz
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mlahso" title="Mlahso">
       Mlahso
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Greek" title="Pontic Greek">
       Pontic Greek
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">
       Romani
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suret" title="Suret">
       Suret
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turoyo" title="Turoyo">
       Turoyo
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ubykh_language" title="Ubykh language">
       Ubykh
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Armenian" title="Western Armenian">
       Western Armenian
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-www.unesco.org_index_276-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-www.unesco.org_index-276">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <br/>
     </p>
