     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
       Religion
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Turkey" title="Religion in Turkey">
       Religion in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Turkey" title="Islam in Turkey">
       Islam in Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Turkey" title="Christianity in Turkey">
       Christianity in Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judaism_in_Turkey" title="Judaism in Turkey">
       Judaism in Turkey
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">
       Secularism in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="barbox tright" style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
      <table style="border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
       <tr style="background:#ddd">
        <th colspan="5">
         <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Turkey" title="Religion in Turkey">
          Religion in Turkey
         </a>
         (2012)
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abs_278-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-abs-278">
           [277]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
        <td style="padding:0 4px;">
         Religion
        </td>
        <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
        </td>
        <td style="width:100px;">
        </td>
        <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
         Percent
        </td>
        <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
         <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
          Islam
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
         <div style="background:green; width:96.5%; overflow: hidden;">
         </div>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
         96.5%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
         <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
          Christianity
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
         <div style="background:red; width:0.3%; overflow: hidden;">
         </div>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
         0.3%
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
         Other/None
        </td>
        <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
         <div style="background:blue; width:3.2%; overflow: hidden;">
         </div>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
         3.2%
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey is a
      <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">
       secular state
      </a>
      with no official
      <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">
       state religion
      </a>
      ; the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">
       Turkish Constitution
      </a>
      provides for
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">
       freedom of religion
      </a>
      and conscience.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
       <a href="#cite_note-279">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
       <a href="#cite_note-280">
        [279]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The role of religion has been a controversial debate over the years since the formation of Islamist parties.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
       <a href="#cite_note-281">
        [280]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For many decades, the wearing of the
      <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">
       hijab
      </a>
      was
      <a href="/wiki/Headscarf_controversy_in_Turkey" title="Headscarf controversy in Turkey">
       banned
      </a>
      in schools and government buildings because it was viewed as a symbol of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_Islam" title="Political Islam">
       political Islam
      </a>
      . However, the ban was lifted from universities in 2011, from government buildings in 2013,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
       <a href="#cite_note-282">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and from schools in 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news24.com_283-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-news24.com-283">
        [282]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Islam">
       Islam
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
       Islam
      </a>
      is the dominant religion of Turkey with 99.8 percent of the population being registered as
      <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">
       Muslim
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_8-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-8">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
       <a href="#cite_note-284">
        [283]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (although some sources give a slightly lower estimate of 96.4 percent)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-joshua_263-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-joshua-263">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
      with the most popular sect being the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hanafite" title="Hanafite">
       Hanafite
      </a>
      school of
      <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">
       Sunni Islam
      </a>
      . The highest Islamic religious authority is the
      <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Religious_Affairs" title="Presidency of Religious Affairs">
       Presidency of Religious Affairs
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
       Turkish
      </a>
      :
      <span lang="tr">
       <i>
        Diyanet İşleri Başkanlığı
       </i>
      </span>
      ); it interprets the
      <a href="/wiki/Hanafi" title="Hanafi">
       Hanafi
      </a>
      school of law, and is responsible for regulating the operation of the country's 80,000 registered mosques and employing local and provincial
      <a href="/wiki/Imam" title="Imam">
       imams
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religiousfreedomreport_285-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-religiousfreedomreport-285">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Academics suggest the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alevi" title="Alevi">
       Alevi
      </a>
      population may be from 15 to 20 million while the Alevi-Bektaşi Federation claims that there are around 25 million
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-usstate_286-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-usstate-286">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-refworld.org1_287-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-refworld.org1-287">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and according to
      <a href="/wiki/Aksiyon" title="Aksiyon">
       Aksiyon
      </a>
      magazine, the number of
      <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">
       Shiite
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">
       Twelvers
      </a>
      (excluding Alevis) is 3 million (4.2 percent).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-caferi_288-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-caferi-288">
        [287]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are also some
      <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">
       Sufi
      </a>
      Muslims.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
       <a href="#cite_note-289">
        [288]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Roughly 2 percent are
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslims" title="Non-denominational Muslims">
       non-denominational Muslims
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewforum.org_290-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pewforum.org-290">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      According to WIN-Gallup International's Global Index of Religiousity and Atheism project,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
       <a href="#cite_note-291">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey is the country with most
      <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Muslim" title="Cultural Muslim">
       irreligious Muslims
      </a>
      in the Islamic world with 73% of its Muslim population. In light of an extensive PEW Global research, only 15% of Muslims in Turkey say prayers for at least one of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salat" title="Salat">
       five prayers
      </a>
      either at home or in a mosque.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
       <a href="#cite_note-292">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Another PEW Report suggests that, only 7% to 13% of all Turks think that religion should have an effect on laws directly or indirectly.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
       <a href="#cite_note-293">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="659" data-file-width="930" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg/220px-Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg/330px-Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg/440px-Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque" title="Sultan Ahmed Mosque">
         Sultan Ahmed Mosque
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
         Istanbul
        </a>
        is popularly known as the Blue Mosque due to the blue
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0znik_tiles" title="İznik tiles">
         İznik tiles
        </a>
        which adorn its interior.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bluemosque_294-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-bluemosque-294">
          [293]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The percentage of non-Muslims in Turkey fell from 19 percent in 1914 to 2.5 percent in 1927,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
       <a href="#cite_note-295">
        [294]
       </a>
      </sup>
      due to events which had a significant impact on the country's demographic structure, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" title="Armenian Genocide">
       Armenian Genocide
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">
       population exchange between Greece and Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
       <a href="#cite_note-296">
        [295]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">
       emigration
      </a>
      of non-Muslims (such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Levantines" title="Levantines">
       Levantines
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">
       Greeks
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">
       Armenians
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
       Jews
      </a>
      , etc.) to foreign countries (mostly in
      <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
       Europe
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Americas" title="The Americas">
       the Americas
      </a>
      ) that actually began in the late 19th century and gained pace in the first quarter of the 20th century, especially during
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
       World War I
      </a>
      and after the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">
       Turkish War of Independence
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
       <a href="#cite_note-297">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Varl%C4%B1k_Vergisi" title="Varlık Vergisi">
       Wealth Tax
      </a>
      on non-Muslims in 1942, the emigration of a portion of Turkish Jews to Israel after 1948, and the ongoing
      <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">
       Cyprus dispute
      </a>
      which damaged the relations between Turks and Greeks (culminating in the
      <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_pogrom" title="Istanbul pogrom">
       Istanbul pogrom
      </a>
      of 6–7 September 1955) were other important events that contributed to the decline of Turkey's non-Muslim population.
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Christianity">
       Christianity
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      Today there are more than 120,000 people of different
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_denominations" title="Christian denominations">
       Christian denominations
      </a>
      , representing less than 0.2 percent of Turkey's population,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-rel_298-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-rel-298">
        [297]
       </a>
      </sup>
      including an estimated 80,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox" title="Oriental Orthodox">
       Oriental Orthodox
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zaman_299-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Zaman-299">
        [298]
       </a>
      </sup>
      35,000
      <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
       Roman Catholics
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-catho_300-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-catho-300">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
      18,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antiochian_Greeks" title="Antiochian Greeks">
       Antiochian Greeks
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
       <a href="#cite_note-301">
        [300]
       </a>
      </sup>
      5,000
      <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">
       Greek Orthodox
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zaman_299-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Zaman-299">
        [298]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and smaller numbers of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestanism" title="Protestanism">
       Protestants
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-christiancentury.org_302-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-christiancentury.org-302">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Currently there are 236 churches open for worship in Turkey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
       <a href="#cite_note-303">
        [302]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
       Eastern Orthodox Church
      </a>
      has been
      <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">
       headquartered in Istanbul
      </a>
      since the 4th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rusch2013_304-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rusch2013-304">
        [303]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FahlbuschBromiley2001_305-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FahlbuschBromiley2001-305">
        [304]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Judaism">
       Judaism
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      There are about 26,000 people who are
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Turkey" title="History of the Jews in Turkey">
       Jewish
      </a>
      , the vast majority of whom are
      <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">
       Sephardi
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
       <a href="#cite_note-306">
        [305]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There have been
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romaniotes" title="Romaniotes">
       Jewish communities in Asia Minor
      </a>
      since at least the 5th century BC and many
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sephardic_Jews" title="Sephardic Jews">
       Spanish and Portuguese Jews
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Alhambra_Decree" title="Alhambra Decree">
       expelled from Spain
      </a>
      were welcomed into the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      in the late 15th century. Despite
      <a href="/wiki/Aliyah" title="Aliyah">
       emigration during the 20th century
      </a>
      , modern-day Turkey continues to have a small Jewish population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-science.co.il_307-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-science.co.il-307">
        [306]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Agnosticism_and_atheism">
       Agnosticism and atheism
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      According to a 2010
      <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
       Eurobarometer
      </a>
      poll 94% of Turks believed in God while only 1% did not. This indicates that 5% of the population are
      <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">
       agnostic
      </a>
      with another 1% being explicitly
      <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">
       atheist
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
       <a href="#cite_note-308">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, according to another poll by KONDA the percentage of atheism is 2.9%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-human.nl_309-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-human.nl-309">
        [308]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Recent polls suggest that 4,5 millions of people were irreligious in 2013. The same data also suggests that 85% of all irreligious people are younger than 35.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
       <a href="#cite_note-310">
        [309]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
       Education
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Turkey" title="Education in Turkey">
       Education in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_high_schools_in_Turkey" title="List of high schools in Turkey">
       List of high schools in Turkey
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Turkey" title="List of universities in Turkey">
       List of universities in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG/220px-Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG/330px-Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG/440px-Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008c.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">
         Istanbul University
        </a>
        was founded in 1453 as a
        <i>
         Darülfünûn
        </i>
        . On 1 August 1933 it was reorganized and became Turkey's first university.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-istanbuluniversity_311-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-istanbuluniversity-311">
          [310]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Education (Turkey)">
       Ministry of National Education
      </a>
      is responsible for pre-tertiary education.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wesed_312-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-wesed-312">
        [311]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This is compulsory and lasts twelve years: four years each of primary school, middle school and high school.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-peg_313-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nyt-peg-313">
        [312]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Less than half of 25- to 34-year-old Turks have completed at least
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_school" title="High school">
       high school
      </a>
      , compared with an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      average of over 80 percent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecdind_314-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-oecdind-314">
        [313]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Basic education in Turkey is considered to lag behind other OECD countries, with significant differences between high and low performers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WBedu_315-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WBedu-315">
        [314]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkey is ranked 32nd out of 34 in the OECD's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PISA" title="PISA">
       PISA
      </a>
      study.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-peg_313-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-nyt-peg-313">
        [312]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Access to high-quality school heavily depends on the performance in the secondary school entrance exams, to the point that some students begin taking private tutoring classes when they are 10 years old.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WBedu_315-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-WBedu-315">
        [314]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The overall adult literacy rate in 2011 was 94.1 percent; 97.9 percent for males and 90.3 percent for females.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unescolit_316-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-unescolit-316">
        [315]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      By 2011, there were 166
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universities_in_Turkey" title="Universities in Turkey">
       universities in Turkey
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
       <a href="#cite_note-317">
        [316]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Entry to higher education depends on the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Student_Selection_Examination" title="Student Selection Examination">
       Student Selection Examination
      </a>
      (ÖSS). In 2008, the quota of admitted students was 600,000, compared to 1,700,000 who took the ÖSS exam in 2007.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Group2009_318-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Group2009-318">
        [317]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Except for the Open Education Faculty (Turkish:
      <i>
       Açıköğretim Fakültesi
      </i>
      ) at
      <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_University" title="Anadolu University">
       Anadolu University
      </a>
      , entrance is regulated by the national ÖSS examination, after which high school graduates are assigned to universities according to their performance.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
       <a href="#cite_note-319">
        [318]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to the 2012–2013
      <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings" title="Times Higher Education World University Rankings">
       Times Higher Education World University Rankings
      </a>
      , the top university in Turkey is
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_Technical_University" title="Middle East Technical University">
       Middle East Technical University
      </a>
      (in the 201–225 rank range), followed by
      <a href="/wiki/Bilkent_University" title="Bilkent University">
       Bilkent University
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ko%C3%A7_University" title="Koç University">
       Koç University
      </a>
      (both in the 226–250 range),
      <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">
       Istanbul Technical University
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_University" title="Boğaziçi University">
       Boğaziçi University
      </a>
      (in the 276–300 bracket).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-therank_320-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-therank-320">
        [319]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">
       Healthcare
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Turkey" title="Health care in Turkey">
       Health care in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_hospitals_in_Turkey" title="List of hospitals in Turkey">
       List of hospitals in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Health care in Turkey used to be dominated by a centralized state system run by the
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Health (Turkey)">
       Ministry of Health
      </a>
      . In 2003, the government introduced a sweeping health reform programme aimed at increasing the ratio of private to state health provision and making healthcare available to a larger share of the population.
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Statistical_Institute" title="Turkish Statistical Institute">
       Turkish Statistical Institute
      </a>
      announced that 76.3 billion
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_lira" title="Turkish lira">
       TL
      </a>
      was spent for healthcare in 2012; 79.6 percent of which was covered by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sosyal_G%C3%BCvenlik_Kurumu" title="Sosyal Güvenlik Kurumu">
       Social Security Institution
      </a>
      and 15.4 percent of which was paid directly by the patients.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
       <a href="#cite_note-321">
        [320]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2012, there were 29,960 medical institutions in Turkey,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TUIKmedical_322-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TUIKmedical-322">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and on average one doctor per 583 people
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
       <a href="#cite_note-323">
        [322]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 2.65 beds per 1000 people.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TUIKmedical_322-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TUIKmedical-322">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
       Life expectancy
      </a>
      (as of 2010
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ) was 71.1 years for men and 75.3 for women, with an overall average of 73.2.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
       <a href="#cite_note-324">
        [323]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
       Culture
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Turkey" title="Culture of Turkey">
       Culture of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Whirlingdervishes.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="707" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/220px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/330px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/440px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Whirlingdervishes.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Whirling Dervishes of the
        <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">
         Sufi
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">
         Mevlevi Order
        </a>
        , founded by the followers of the 13th-century Sufi
        <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">
         mystic
        </a>
        and poet
        <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">
         Rumi
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
         Konya
        </a>
        , during a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sema" title="Sema">
         Sema
        </a>
        . The ceremony is one of the 11 elements of Turkey on the
        <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">
         UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unesco1_325-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-unesco1-325">
          [324]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkey has a very diverse culture that is a blend of various elements of the
      <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">
       Turkic
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
       Anatolian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman
      </a>
      (which was itself a continuation of both
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greco-Roman" title="Greco-Roman">
       Greco-Roman
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">
       Islamic
      </a>
      cultures) and
      <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">
       Western culture
      </a>
      and traditions, which started with the
      <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
       Westernisation of the Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      and still continues today. This mix originally began as a result of the encounter of Turks and their culture with those of the peoples who were in their path during
      <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">
       their migration
      </a>
      from Central Asia to the West.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_culture_326-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-326">
        [325]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
       <a href="#cite_note-327">
        [326]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Turkish culture is a product of efforts to be a "modern" Western state, while maintaining traditional religious and historical values.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_culture_326-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-326">
        [325]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">
       Arts
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arts_in_Turkey" title="Arts in Turkey">
       Arts in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_painting" title="Turkish painting">
       Turkish painting
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">
       Turkish literature
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">
       Turkish dance
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folklore" title="Turkish folklore">
       Turkish folklore
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">
       Music of Turkey
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Turkey" title="Theatre of Turkey">
       Theatre of Turkey
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals_in_Turkey" title="Festivals in Turkey">
       Festivals in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3659" data-file-width="2004" height="274" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/150px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/225px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/300px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/The_Tortoise_Trainer" title="The Tortoise Trainer">
          The Tortoise Trainer
         </a>
        </i>
        by
        <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">
         Osman Hamdi Bey
        </a>
        , at the
        <a href="/wiki/Pera_Museum" title="Pera Museum">
         Pera Museum
        </a>
        in Istanbul.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Turkish_painters" title="List of Turkish painters">
       Turkish painting
      </a>
      , in the Western sense, developed actively starting from the mid 19th century. The very first painting lessons were scheduled at what is now the
      <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">
       Istanbul Technical University
      </a>
      (then the
      <i>
       Imperial Military Engineering School
      </i>
      ) in 1793, mostly for technical purposes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarriOhta1999_328-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-HarriOhta1999-328">
        [327]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the late 19th century, human figure in the western sense was being established in Turkish painting, especially with
      <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">
       Osman Hamdi Bey
      </a>
      . Impressionism, among the contemporary trends, appeared later on with Halil Paşa. The young Turkish artists sent to Europe in 1926 came back inspired by contemporary trends such as Fauvism, Cubism and even Expressionism, still very influential in Europe. The later "Group D" of artists led by
      <a href="/wiki/Abidin_Dino" title="Abidin Dino">
       Abidin Dino
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cemal_Tollu" title="Cemal Tollu">
       Cemal Tollu
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fikret_Mualla" title="Fikret Mualla">
       Fikret Mualla
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Princess_Fahrelnissa_Zeid" title="Princess Fahrelnissa Zeid">
       Fahrünnisa Zeid
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bedri_Rahmi_Eyuboglu" title="Bedri Rahmi Eyuboglu">
       Bedri Rahmi Eyüboğlu
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Adnan_Coker" title="Adnan Coker">
       Adnan Çoker
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Burhan_Do%C4%9Fan%C3%A7ay" title="Burhan Doğançay">
       Burhan Doğançay
      </a>
      introduced some trends that had lasted in the West for more than three decades. Other important movements in Turkish painting were the "Yeniler Grubu" (The Newcomers Group) of the late 1930s; the "On'lar Grubu" (Group of Ten) of the 1940s; the "Yeni Dal Grubu" (New Branch Group) of the 1950s; and the "Siyah Kalem Grubu" (Black Pen Group) of the 1960s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkresmi.com_329-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-turkresmi.com-329">
        [328]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="806" data-file-width="600" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png/150px-Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png/225px-Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png/300px-Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A 13th century
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" title="Turkish carpet">
         Turkish carpet
        </a>
        from the
        <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">
         Anatolian Seljuk Sultanate
        </a>
        period, originally at the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alaeddin_Mosque" title="Alaeddin Mosque">
         Alaeddin Mosque
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
         Konya
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
         <a href="#cite_note-330">
          [329]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">
       Turkish music
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">
       literature
      </a>
      are examples of a mix of cultural influences. Interaction between the Ottoman Empire and the Islamic world along with Europe contributed to a blend of Turkic, Islamic and European traditions in modern-day Turkish music and literary arts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ottomus_331-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ottomus-331">
        [330]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">
       Turkish literature
      </a>
      was heavily influenced by
      <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">
       Persian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">
       Arabic literature
      </a>
      during most of the Ottoman era. The
      <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
       Tanzimat
      </a>
      reforms introduced previously unknown Western genres, primarily the novel and the short story. Many of the writers in the Tanzimat period wrote in several genres simultaneously: for instance, the poet
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Namik_Kemal" title="Namik Kemal">
       Nâmık Kemal
      </a>
      also wrote the important 1876 novel
      <i>
       İntibâh
      </i>
      (Awakening), while the journalist
      <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0brahim_%C5%9Einasi" title="İbrahim Şinasi">
       Şinasi
      </a>
      is noted for writing, in 1860, the first modern Turkish play, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_act_play" title="One act play">
       one-act
      </a>
      comedy "
      <i>
       Şair Evlenmesi
      </i>
      " (The Poet's Marriage). Most of the roots of modern Turkish literature were formed between the years 1896 and 1923. Broadly, there were three primary literary movements during this period: the
      <i>
       Edebiyyât-ı Cedîde
      </i>
      (New Literature) movement; the
      <i>
       Fecr-i Âtî
      </i>
      (Dawn of the Future) movement; and the
      <i>
       Millî Edebiyyât
      </i>
      (National Literature) movement. The first radical step of innovation in 20th century Turkish poetry was taken by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C3%A2z%C4%B1m_Hikmet_Ran" title="Nâzım Hikmet Ran">
       Nâzım Hikmet
      </a>
      , who introduced the
      <a href="/wiki/Free_verse" title="Free verse">
       free verse
      </a>
      style. Another revolution in Turkish poetry came about in 1941 with the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Garip_Movement" title="Garip Movement">
       Garip Movement
      </a>
      . The mix of cultural influences in Turkey is dramatized, for example, in the form of the "new symbols of the clash and interlacing of cultures" enacted in the novels of
      <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">
       Orhan Pamuk
      </a>
      , recipient of the 2006
      <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">
       Nobel Prize in Literature
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
       <a href="#cite_note-332">
        [331]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Turkey has a
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">
       diverse folkloric dance
      </a>
      culture.
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Hora_(dance)" title="Hora (dance)">
        Hora
       </a>
      </i>
      is performed in
      <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">
       East Thrace
      </a>
      ;
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Zeybek_dance" title="Zeybek dance">
        Zeybek
       </a>
      </i>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Region" title="Aegean Region">
       Aegean Region
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">
       Southern Marmara
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">
       East-Central Anatolia Region
      </a>
      ;
      <i>
       Teke
      </i>
      in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" title="Mediterranean Region">
       Western Mediterranean Region
      </a>
      ;
      <i>
       Kaşık Oyunları
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kar%C5%9F%C4%B1lama" title="Karşılama">
        Karşılama
       </a>
      </i>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">
       West-Central Anatolia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">
       Western Black Sea Region
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">
       Southern Marmara Region
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" title="Mediterranean Region">
       Eastern Mediterranean Region
      </a>
      ;
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Horon" title="Horon">
        Horon
       </a>
      </i>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">
       Central and Eastern Black Sea Region
      </a>
      ;
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Halay" title="Halay">
        Halay
       </a>
      </i>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">
       Eastern Anatolia
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">
       Central Anatolia Region
      </a>
      ; and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Bar_(dance)" title="Bar (dance)">
        Bar
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Lezginka" title="Lezginka">
        Lezginka
       </a>
      </i>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">
       Northeastern Anatolia Region
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-.ncturkishfestival._333-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-.ncturkishfestival.-333">
        [332]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
       Architecture
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey" title="Architecture of Turkey">
       Architecture of Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">
       Byzantine architecture
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">
       Seljuk architecture
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">
       Ottoman architecture
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/200px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/300px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/400px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1865" data-file-width="2417" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/200px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/300px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/400px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">
          Grand Post Office
         </a>
         (1905–1909) in Istanbul and the first
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ziraat_Bank" title="Ziraat Bank">
          Ziraat Bank
         </a>
         headquarters (1925–1929) in Ankara are among the examples of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" title="First National Architectural Movement">
          Turkish Neoclassical architecture
         </a>
         in the early 20th century.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">
       architecture of the Seljuk Turks
      </a>
      combined the elements and characteristics of the
      <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Central_Asia" title="Architecture of Central Asia">
       Turkic architecture of Central Asia
      </a>
      with those of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_architecture" title="Persian architecture">
       Persian
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_architecture" title="Arab architecture">
       Arab
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Armenian_architecture" title="Armenian architecture">
       Armenian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">
       Byzantine
      </a>
      architecture. The transition from Seljuk architecture to
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">
       Ottoman architecture
      </a>
      is most visible in
      <a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">
       Bursa
      </a>
      , which was the capital of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman State
      </a>
      between 1335 and 1413. Following the
      <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">
       Ottoman conquest of Constantinople (Istanbul)
      </a>
      in 1453, Ottoman architecture was significantly influenced by
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">
       Byzantine architecture
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="Topkapı Palace">
       Topkapı Palace
      </a>
      in Istanbul is one of the most famous examples of classical Ottoman architecture and was the primary residence of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Sultan" title="Ottoman Sultan">
       Ottoman Sultans
      </a>
      for approximately 400 years.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_334-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-334">
        [333]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">
       Mimar Sinan
      </a>
      (c.1489–1588) was the most important architect of the classical period in Ottoman architecture. He was the chief architect of at least 374 buildings which were constructed in various
      <a href="/wiki/Eyalet" title="Eyalet">
       provinces
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      in the 16th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335">
       <a href="#cite_note-335">
        [334]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Since the 18th century, Turkish architecture has been increasingly influenced by European styles, and this can be particularly seen in the
      <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
       Tanzimat
      </a>
      era buildings of Istanbul like the
      <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">
       Dolmabahçe
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/%C3%87%C4%B1ra%C4%9Fan_Palace" title="Çırağan Palace">
       Çırağan
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feriye_Saraylar%C4%B1" title="Feriye Sarayları">
       Feriye
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Beylerbeyi_Palace" title="Beylerbeyi Palace">
       Beylerbeyi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace" title="Küçüksu Palace">
       Küçüksu
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ihlamur_Palace" title="Ihlamur Palace">
       Ihlamur
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_Palace" title="Yıldız Palace">
       Yıldız
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Palace" title="Palace">
       palaces
      </a>
      , which were all designed by members of the
      <a href="/wiki/Balyan_family" title="Balyan family">
       Balyan family
      </a>
      of Ottoman court architects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336">
       <a href="#cite_note-336">
        [335]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Ottoman era
      <a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="Yalı">
       waterfront houses (
       <i>
        yalı
       </i>
       )
      </a>
      on the
      <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
       Bosphorus
      </a>
      also reflect the fusion between classical Ottoman and European architectural styles during the aforementioned period. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" title="First National Architectural Movement">
       First National Architectural Movement
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       Birinci Ulusal Mimarlık Akımı
      </i>
      ) in the early 20th century sought to create a new architecture, which was based on motifs from Seljuk and Ottoman architecture. The movement was also labelled
      <i>
       Turkish Neoclassical
      </i>
      or the
      <i>
       National Architectural Renaissance
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-First_337-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-First-337">
        [336]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The leading architects of this movement were
      <a href="/wiki/Vedat_Tek" title="Vedat Tek">
       Vedat Tek
      </a>
      (1873–1942),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mimar_Kemaleddin_Bey" title="Mimar Kemaleddin Bey">
       Mimar Kemaleddin Bey
      </a>
      (1870–1927),
      <a href="/wiki/Arif_Hikmet_Koyuno%C4%9Flu" title="Arif Hikmet Koyunoğlu">
       Arif Hikmet Koyunoğlu
      </a>
      (1888–1982) and Giulio Mongeri (1873–1953).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkisharch_338-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-turkisharch-338">
        [337]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Notable buildings from this era are the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">
       Grand Post Office
      </a>
      in Istanbul (1905–1909),
      <a href="/wiki/Tayyare_Apartments" title="Tayyare Apartments">
       Tayyare Apartments
      </a>
      (1919–1922),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tayyare_339-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-tayyare-339">
        [338]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_4th_Vak%C4%B1f_Han" title="Istanbul 4th Vakıf Han">
       Istanbul 4th Vakıf Han
      </a>
      (1911–1926),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340">
       <a href="#cite_note-340">
        [339]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/State_Art_and_Sculpture_Museum" title="State Art and Sculpture Museum">
       State Art and Sculpture Museum
      </a>
      (1927–1930),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stateart_341-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-stateart-341">
        [340]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Ethnography_Museum_of_Ankara" title="Ethnography Museum of Ankara">
       Ethnography Museum of Ankara
      </a>
      (1925–1928),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnography_342-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ethnography-342">
        [341]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the first
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ziraat_Bank" title="Ziraat Bank">
       Ziraat Bank
      </a>
      headquarters in Ankara (1925–1929),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
       <a href="#cite_note-343">
        [342]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the first
      <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_%C4%B0%C5%9F_Bankas%C4%B1" title="Türkiye İş Bankası">
       Türkiye İş Bankası
      </a>
      headquarters in Ankara (1926–1929),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-i.C5.9Fbank_344-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-i.C5.9Fbank-344">
        [343]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Bebek,_Istanbul" title="Bebek, Istanbul">
       Bebek
      </a>
      Mosque,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bebek_345-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bebek-345">
        [344]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and Kamer Hatun Mosque.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kamer_346-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-kamer-346">
        [345]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mass_347-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mass-347">
        [346]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
       Sports
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_Turkey" title="Sports in Turkey">
       Sports in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Turkey" title="Football in Turkey">
       Football in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/220px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/330px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/440px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Turkey_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey national basketball team">
         Turkey
        </a>
        won the silver medal at the
        <a href="/wiki/2010_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2010 FIBA World Championship">
         2010 FIBA World Championship
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The most popular
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_Turkey" title="Sports in Turkey">
       sport in Turkey
      </a>
      is
      <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
       association football
      </a>
      (soccer).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348">
       <a href="#cite_note-348">
        [347]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(football)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (football)">
       Galatasaray
      </a>
      won the
      <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Cup_Final" title="2000 UEFA Cup Final">
       UEFA Cup
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2000 UEFA Super Cup">
       UEFA Super Cup
      </a>
      in 2000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uefa.com_349-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-uefa.com-349">
        [348]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_national_football_team" title="Turkish national football team">
       Turkish national football team
      </a>
      finished 3rd and won the bronze medal at the
      <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">
       2002 FIFA World Cup
      </a>
      and at the
      <a href="/wiki/2003_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2003 FIFA Confederations Cup">
       2003 FIFA Confederations Cup
      </a>
      ; while also reaching the semi-finals (finishing 3rd by goals difference) at the
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008" title="UEFA Euro 2008">
       UEFA Euro 2008
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tff.org1_350-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-tff.org1-350">
        [349]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Other mainstream sports such as
      <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">
       basketball
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">
       volleyball
      </a>
      are also popular. The
      <a href="/wiki/Turkey_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey national basketball team">
       Turkish men's national basketball team
      </a>
      finished 2nd and won the silver medal at the
      <a href="/wiki/2010_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2010 FIBA World Championship">
       2010 FIBA World Championship
      </a>
      and at
      <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2001" title="EuroBasket 2001">
       EuroBasket 2001
      </a>
      , which were both hosted by Turkey. They also won two gold medals (1987 and 2013), one silver medal (1971) and three bronze medals (1967, 1983 and 2009) at the
      <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Mediterranean_Games" title="Basketball at the Mediterranean Games">
       Mediterranean Games
      </a>
      . Turkish basketball club
      <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_Efes_S.K." title="Anadolu Efes S.K.">
       Anadolu Efes S.K.
      </a>
      won the
      <a href="/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_FIBA_Kora%C4%87_Cup" title="1995–96 FIBA Korać Cup">
       1995–96
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Kora%C4%87_Cup" title="FIBA Korać Cup">
       FIBA Korać Cup
      </a>
      , finished 2nd at the
      <a href="/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_FIBA_European_Cup" title="1992–93 FIBA European Cup">
       1992–93
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Saporta_Cup" title="FIBA Saporta Cup">
       FIBA Saporta Cup
      </a>
      , and made it to the Final Four of
      <a href="/wiki/Euroleague_Basketball" title="Euroleague Basketball">
       Euroleague
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_SuproLeague" title="FIBA SuproLeague">
       Suproleague
      </a>
      in 2000 and 2001, finishing 3rd on both occasions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
       <a href="#cite_note-351">
        [350]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
       <a href="#cite_note-352">
        [351]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Another Turkish basketball club,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_men%27s_basketball_team" title="Beşiktaş men's basketball team">
       Beşiktaş
      </a>
      , won the
      <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_FIBA_EuroChallenge" title="2011–12 FIBA EuroChallenge">
       2011–12
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/EuroChallenge" title="EuroChallenge">
       FIBA EuroChallenge
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fibaeurope.com1_353-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fibaeurope.com1-353">
        [352]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(men%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (men's basketball)">
       Galatasaray
      </a>
      won the
      <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Eurocup_Basketball" title="2015–16 Eurocup Basketball">
       2015–16 Eurocup
      </a>
      , while in the same season,
      <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Men%27s_Basketball" title="Fenerbahçe Men's Basketball">
       Fenerbahçe
      </a>
      finished second in the
      <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Euroleague" title="2015–16 Euroleague">
       2015–16 Euroleague
      </a>
      . The Final of the
      <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_EuroLeague_Women" title="2013–14 EuroLeague Women">
       2013–14 EuroLeague Women
      </a>
      basketball championship was played between two Turkish teams,
      <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(women%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (women's basketball)">
       Galatasaray
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Basketball" title="Fenerbahçe Women's Basketball">
       Fenerbahçe
      </a>
      , and won by Galatasaray.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fibaeurope.com2_354-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fibaeurope.com2-354">
        [353]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Turkey women's national volleyball team">
       Turkish women's national volleyball team
      </a>
      won the silver medal at the
      <a href="/wiki/2003_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2003 Women's European Volleyball Championship">
       2003 European Championship
      </a>
      , the bronze medal at the
      <a href="/wiki/2011_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2011 Women's European Volleyball Championship">
       2011 European Championship
      </a>
      , and the bronze medal at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2012_FIVB_World_Grand_Prix" title="2012 FIVB World Grand Prix">
       2012 FIVB World Grand Prix
      </a>
      . They also won a gold medal (2005), six silver medals (1987, 1991, 1997, 2001, 2009, 2013) and a bronze medal (1993) at the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Games" title="Mediterranean Games">
       Mediterranean Games
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tvf.org.tr_355-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-tvf.org.tr-355">
        [354]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Women's volleyball clubs in Turkey, namely
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Ac%C4%B1badem" title="Fenerbahçe Acıbadem">
       Fenerbahçe
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1_Istanbul" title="Eczacıbaşı Istanbul">
       Eczacıbaşı
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Vak%C4%B1fbank_Spor_Kul%C3%BCb%C3%BC" title="Vakıfbank Spor Kulübü">
       Vakıfbank
      </a>
      , have won numerous European championship titles and medals.
      <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Volleyball" title="Fenerbahçe Women's Volleyball">
       Fenerbahçe
      </a>
      won the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2010_FIVB_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2010 FIVB Women's Club World Championship">
       2010 FIVB Women's Club World Championship
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="CEV Women's Champions League">
       2012 CEV Women's Champions League
      </a>
      . Representing
      <a href="/wiki/European_Volleyball_Confederation" title="European Volleyball Confederation">
       Europe
      </a>
      as the winner of the
      <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="2012–13 CEV Women's Champions League">
       2012–13 CEV Women's Champions League
      </a>
      , Vakıfbank also became the world champion by winning the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2013_FIVB_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2013 FIVB Women's Club World Championship">
       2013 FIVB Women's Club World Championship
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fenerbahce.org.tr_356-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fenerbahce.org.tr-356">
        [355]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr_357-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr-357">
        [356]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hurriyet.com.tr1_358-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hurriyet.com.tr1-358">
        [357]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The traditional Turkish national sport has been
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ya%C4%9Fl%C4%B1_g%C3%BCre%C5%9F" title="Yağlı güreş">
       yağlı güreş
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       oiled wrestling
      </i>
      ) since Ottoman times.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359">
       <a href="#cite_note-359">
        [358]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">
       Edirne
      </a>
      has hosted the annual
      <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1rkp%C4%B1nar" title="Kırkpınar">
       Kırkpınar
      </a>
      oiled wrestling tournament since 1361.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360">
       <a href="#cite_note-360">
        [359]
       </a>
      </sup>
      International wrestling styles governed by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Associated_Wrestling_Styles" title="International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles">
       FILA
      </a>
      such as
      <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_wrestling" title="Freestyle wrestling">
       Freestyle wrestling
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_wrestling" title="Greco-Roman wrestling">
       Greco-Roman wrestling
      </a>
      are also popular, with many European, World and Olympic championship titles won by Turkish wrestlers both individually and as a national team.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361">
       <a href="#cite_note-361">
        [360]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
       Cuisine
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">
       Turkish cuisine
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">
       Ottoman cuisine
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1719" data-file-width="2510" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/220px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/330px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/440px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_coffee" title="Turkish coffee">
         Turkish coffee
        </a>
        with
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_delight" title="Turkish delight">
         Turkish delight
        </a>
        . Turkish coffee is a
        <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">
         UNESCO-listed intangible cultural heritage
        </a>
        of
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
         Turks
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
         <a href="#cite_note-362">
          [361]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363">
         <a href="#cite_note-363">
          [362]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Turkish cuisine is regarded as one of the most prominent in the world, its popularity is largely owed to the cultural influences of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      and partly because of its major tourism industry. It is largely the heritage of
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">
       Ottoman cuisine
      </a>
      , which can be described as a fusion and refinement of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Asian_cuisine" title="Central Asian cuisine">
       Central Asian
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caucasian_cuisine" title="Caucasian cuisine">
       Caucasian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_cuisine" title="Middle Eastern cuisine">
       Middle Eastern
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">
       Mediterranean
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Balkan_cuisine" title="Balkan cuisine">
       Balkan
      </a>
      cuisines.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364">
       <a href="#cite_note-364">
        [363]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The country's position between the East and the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
       Mediterranean Sea
      </a>
      helped the Turks gain complete control of major trade routes, and an ideal environment allowed plants and animals to flourish. Turkish cuisine was well established by the mid-1400s, the beginning of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      's six hundred-year reign. Yogurt salads, fish in
      <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">
       olive oil
      </a>
      , and stuffed and wrapped vegetables became Turkish staples. The empire, eventually spanning from Austria to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Africa" title="Northern Africa">
       northern Africa
      </a>
      , used its land and water routes to import exotic ingredients from all over the world. By the end of the 16th century, the Ottoman court housed over 1,400 live-in cooks and passed laws regulating the freshness of food. Since the fall of the empire in World War I (1914–1918) and the establishment of the Turkish Republic in 1923, foreign food such as French hollandaise sauce and western fast food have made their way into the modern Turkish diet.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-foodbycountry.com_365-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-foodbycountry.com-365">
        [364]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
       Media
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_in_Turkey" title="Media in Turkey">
       Media in Turkey
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Hundreds of television channels, thousands of local and national radio stations, several dozen newspapers, a productive and profitable
      <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">
       national cinema
      </a>
      and a rapid growth of
      <a href="/wiki/Broadband" title="Broadband">
       broadband
      </a>
      internet use all make up a very vibrant media industry in Turkey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tesevmedya_366-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-tesevmedya-366">
        [365]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2003 a total of 257 television stations and 1,100 radio stations were licensed to operate, and others operated without licenses. Of those licensed, 16 television and 36 radio stations reached national audiences.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_367-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-cp-367">
        [366]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The majority of the audiences are shared among public broadcaster
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">
       TRT
      </a>
      and the network-style channels such as
      <a href="/wiki/Kanal_D" title="Kanal D">
       Kanal D
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Show_TV" title="Show TV">
       Show TV
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/ATV_(Turkey)" title="ATV (Turkey)">
       ATV
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Star_TV_(Turkey)" title="Star TV (Turkey)">
       Star TV
      </a>
      . The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broadcast_media" title="Broadcast media">
       broadcast media
      </a>
      have a very high penetration as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satellite_dishes" title="Satellite dishes">
       satellite dishes
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Cable_television" title="Cable television">
       cable
      </a>
      systems are widely available.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_367-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-cp-367">
        [366]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RT%C3%9CK" title="RTÜK">
       Radio and Television Supreme Council (RTÜK)
      </a>
      is the government body overseeing the broadcast media.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_367-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-cp-367">
        [366]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By circulation, the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Turkey" title="List of newspapers in Turkey">
       most popular newspapers
      </a>
      are
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Posta_(newspaper)" title="Posta (newspaper)">
        Posta
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/H%C3%BCrriyet" title="Hürriyet">
        Hürriyet
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B6zc%C3%BC" title="Sözcü">
        Sözcü
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Sabah_(newspaper)" title="Sabah (newspaper)">
        Sabah
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Habert%C3%BCrk" title="Habertürk">
        Habertürk
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368">
       <a href="#cite_note-368">
        [367]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Turkish_television_drama" title="Turkish television drama">
       Turkish television dramas
      </a>
      are increasingly becoming popular beyond Turkey's borders and are among the country's most vital exports, both in terms of profit and public relations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369">
       <a href="#cite_note-369">
        [368]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After sweeping the
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">
       Middle East
      </a>
      's television market over the past decade, Turkish shows have aired in more than a dozen
      <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">
       South
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">
       Central American
      </a>
      countries in 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370">
       <a href="#cite_note-370">
        [369]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
       Freedom House
      </a>
      lists Turkey's media as "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Turkey" title="Censorship in Turkey">
       partly free
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_116-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-116">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
